verses.text: The treatise gives a remarkable specimen of Jerome's system of interpreting Scripture, and also of the methods by which asceticism was introduced into the Church, and marriage brought into disesteem.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:30
verses.text: Very few days have elapsed since the holy brethren of Rome sent to me the treatises of a certain Jovinian with the request that I would reply to the follies contained in them, and would crush with evangelical and apostolic vigour theEpicurus of Christianity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:31
verses.text: I read but could not in the least comprehend them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:32
verses.text: I began therefore to give them closer attention, and to thoroughly sift not only words and sentences, but almost every single syllable; for I wished first to ascertain his meaning, and then to approve, or refute what he had said.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:33
verses.text: But the style is so barbarous, and the language so vile and such a heap of blunders, that I could neither understand what he was talking about, nor by what arguments he was trying to prove his points.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:34
verses.text: At one moment he is all bombast, at another he grovels: from time to time he lifts himself up, and then like a wounded snake finds his own effort too much for him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:35
verses.text: Not satisfied with the language of men, he attempts something loftier.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:36
verses.text: "The mountains labour; a poor mouse is born".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:37
verses.text: "That he's gone mad ev'n mad Orestes swears".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:38
verses.text: Moreover he involves everything in such inextricable confusion that the saying ofPlautus might be applied to him:—"This is what none but a Sibyl will ever read".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:39
verses.text: To understand him we must be prophets.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:40
verses.text: We read Apollo's raving prophetesses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:41
verses.text: We remember, too, whatVirgil says of senseless noise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:42
verses.text: Heraclitus, also, surnamed the Obscure, the philosophers find hard to understand even with their utmost toil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:43
verses.text: But what are they compared with our riddle-maker, whose books are much more difficult to comprehend than to refute? Although (we must confess) the task of refuting them is no easy one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 1:44
verses.text: For how can you overcome a man when you are quite in the dark as to his meaning? But, not to be tedious to my reader, the introduction to his second book, of which he has discharged himself like a sot after a night's debauch, will show the character of his eloquence, and through what bright flowers of rhetoric he takes his stately course.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 2:2
verses.text: "I respond to your invitation, not that I may go through life with a high reputation, but may live free from idle rumour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 2:3
verses.text: I beseech the ground, the young shoots of our plantations, the plants and trees of tenderness snatched from the whirlpool of vice, to grant me audience and the support of many listeners.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 2:4
verses.text: We know that the Church through hope, faith, charity, is inaccessible and impregnable.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 2:5
verses.text: In it no one is immature: all are apt to learn: none can force a way into it by violence, or deceive it by craft".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:2
verses.text: What, I ask, is the meaning of these portentous words and of this grotesque description? Would you not think he was in a feverish dream, or that he was seized with madness and ought to be put into the strait jacket which Hippocrates prescribed? However often I read him, even till my heart sinks within me, I am still in uncertainty of his meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:3
verses.text: Everything starts from, everything depends upon, something else.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:4
verses.text: It is impossible to make out any connection; and, excepting the proofs from Scripture which he has not dared to exchange for his own lovely flowers of rhetoric, his words suit all matter equally well, because they suit no matter at all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:5
verses.text: This circumstance led me shrewdly to suspect that his object in proclaiming the excellence of marriage was only to disparage virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:6
verses.text: For when the less is put upon a level with the greater, the lower profits by comparison, but the higher suffers wrong.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:7
verses.text: For ourselves, we do not follow the views ofMarcion and Manichaeus, and disparage marriage; nor, deceived by the error ofTatian, the leader of the Encratites, do we think all intercourse impure; he condemns and rejects not only marriage but also food which God created for the use of man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:8
verses.text: We know that in a great house, there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and earthenware.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:9
verses.text: And that upon the foundation, Christ, which Paul the master-builder laid, some build gold, silver, precious stones: others, on the contrary, hay, wood, straw.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:10
verses.text: We are not ignorant of the words,"Marriage is honourable among all, and the bed undefiled".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:11
verses.text: We have read God's first command, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth"; but while we honour marriage we prefer virginity which is the offspring of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:12
verses.text: Will silver cease to be silver, if gold is more precious than silver? Or is despite done to tree and corn, if we prefer the fruit to root and foliage, or the grain to stalk and ear? Virginity is to marriage what fruit is to the tree, or grain to the straw.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:13
verses.text: Although the hundred-fold, the sixty-fold, and the thirty-fold spring from one earth and from one sowing, yet there is a great difference in respect of number.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:14
verses.text: The thirty-fold has reference to marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:15
verses.text: The very way thefingers are combined—see how they seem to embrace, tenderly kiss, and pledge their troth either to other—is a picture of husband and wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:16
verses.text: The sixty-fold applies to widows, because they are placed in a position of difficulty and distress.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:17
verses.text: Hence the upper finger signifies their depression, and the greater the difficulty in resisting the allurements of pleasure once experienced, the greater the reward.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:18
verses.text: Moreover (give good heed, my reader), to denote a hundred, the right hand is used instead of the left: a circle is made with the same fingers which on the left hand represented widowhood, and thus the crown of virginity is expressed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:19
verses.text: In saying this I have followed my own impatient spirit rather than the course of the argument.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:20
verses.text: For I had scarcely left harbour, and had barely hoisted sail, when a swelling tide of words suddenly swept me into the depths of the discussion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:21
verses.text: I must stay my course, and take in canvas for a little while; nor will I indulge my sword, anxious as it is to strike a blow for virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:22
verses.text: The farther back the catapult is drawn, the greater the force of the missile.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:23
verses.text: To linger is not to lose, if by lingering victory is better assured.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:24
verses.text: I will briefly set forth our adversary's views, and will drag them out from his books like snakes from the holes where they hide, and will separate the venomous head from the writhing body.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:25
verses.text: What is baneful shall be discovered, that, when we have the power, it may be crushed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:26
verses.text: He says that "virgins, widows, and married women, who have been once passed through the laver of Christ, if they are on a par in other respects, are of equal merit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:27
verses.text: He endeavours to show that "they who with full assurance of faith have been born again in baptism, cannot be overthrown by the devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:28
verses.text: His third point is "that there is no difference between abstinence from food, and its reception with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 3:29
verses.text: The fourth and last is "that there is one reward in the kingdom of heaven for all who have kept their baptismal vow".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:2
verses.text: This is the hissing of the old serpent; by counsel such as this the dragon drove man from Paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:3
verses.text: For he promised that if they would prefer fulness to fasting they should be immortal, as though it were an impossibility for them to fall; and while he promises they shall be as Gods, he drives them from Paradise, with the result that they who, while naked and unhampered, and as virgins unspotted enjoyed the fellowship of the Lord were cast down into the vale of tears, and sewed skins together to clothe themselves withal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:4
verses.text: But, not to detain the reader any longer, I will keep to the division given above and taking his propositions one by one will rely chiefly on the evidence of Scripture to refute them, for fear he may chatter and complain that he was overcome by rhetorical skill rather than by force of truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:5
verses.text: If I succeed in this and with the aid of a cloud of witnesses from both Testaments prove too strong for him, I will then accept his challenge, and adduce illustrations from secular literature.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:6
verses.text: I will show that even among philosophers and distinguished statesmen, the virtuous are wont to be preferred by all to the voluptuous, that is to say men likePythagoras,Plato andAristides, toAristippus,Epicurus andAlcibiades.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:7
verses.text: I entreat virgins of both sexes and all such as are continent, the married also and the twice married, to assist my efforts with their prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:8
verses.text: Jovinian is the common enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:9
verses.text: For he who maintains all to be of equal merit, does no less injury to virginity in comparing it with marriage than he does to marriage, when he allows it to be lawful, but to the same extent as second and third marriages.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:10
verses.text: But to digamists and trigamists also he does wrong, for he places on a level with them whoremongers and the most licentious persons as soon as they have repented; but perhaps those who have been married twice or thrice ought not to complain, for the same whoremonger if penitent is made equal in the kingdom of heaven even to virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:11
verses.text: I will therefore explain more clearly and in proper sequence the arguments he employs and the illustrations he adduces respecting marriage, and will treat them in the order in which he states them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:12
verses.text: And I beg the reader not to be disturbed if he is compelled to read Jovinian's nauseating trash.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:13
verses.text: He will all the more gladly drink Christ's antidote after the devil's poisonous concoction.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:14
verses.text: Listen with patience, ye virgins; listen, I pray you, to the voice of the most voluptuous of preachers; nay rather close your ears, as you would to the Syren's fabled songs, and pass on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 4:15
verses.text: For a little while endure the wrongs you suffer: think you are crucified with Christ, and are listening to the blasphemies of the Pharisees.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:2
verses.text: First of all, he says, God declares that"therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:3
verses.text: And lest we should say that this is a quotation from the Old Testament, he asserts that it has been confirmed by the Lord in the Gospel—"What God hath joined together, let not man put asunder": and he immediately adds, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:4
verses.text: He next repeats the names of Seth, Enos, Cainan, Mahalalel, Jared, Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech, Noah, and tells us that they all had wives and in accordance with the will of God begot sons, as though there could be any table of descent or any history of mankind without wives and children.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:5
verses.text: "There," says he, "is Enoch, who walked with God and was carried up to heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:6
verses.text: There is Noah, the only person who, except his wife, and his sons and their wives, was saved at the deluge, although there must have been many persons not of marriageable age, and therefore presumably virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:7
verses.text: Again, after the deluge, when the human race started as it were anew, men and women were paired together and a fresh blessing was pronounced on procreation, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:8
verses.text: Moreover, free permission was given to eat flesh, "Every moving thing that liveth shall be food for you; as the green herb have I given you all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:9
verses.text: He then flies off to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, of whom the first had three wives, the second one, the third four, Leah, Rachel, Billah, and Zilpah, and he declares that Abraham by his faith merited the blessing which he received in begetting his son.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:10
verses.text: Sarah, typifying the Church, when it had ceased to be with her after the manner of women, exchanged the curse of barrenness for the blessing of child-bearing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:11
verses.text: We are informed that Rebekah went like a prophet to inquire of the Lord, and was told, "Two nations and two peoples are in thy womb," that Jacob served for his wife, and that when Rachel, thinking it was in the power of her husband to give her children, said, "Give me children, or else I die," he replied, "Am I in God's stead, who hath withheld from thee the fruit of the womb?" so well aware was he that the fruit of marriage cometh from the Lord and not from the husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:12
verses.text: We next learn that Joseph, a holy man of spotless chastity, and all the patriarchs, had wives, and that God blessed them all alike through the lips of Moses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:13
verses.text: Judah also and Thamar are brought upon the scene, and he censures Onan, slain by the Lord, because he, grudging to raise up seed to his brother, marred the marriage rite.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:14
verses.text: He refers to Moses and the leprosy of Miriam, who, because she chided her brother on account of his wife, was stricken by the avenging hand of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:15
verses.text: He praises Samson, I may even say extravagantly panegyrizes the uxorious Nazarite.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:16
verses.text: Deborah also and Barak are mentioned, because, although they had not the benefit of virginity, they were victorious over the iron chariots of Sisera and Jabin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:17
verses.text: He brings forward Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, and extols her for arming herself with thestake.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:18
verses.text: He says there was no difference between Jephthah and his virgin daughter, who was sacrificed to the Lord: nay, of the two, he prefers the faith of the father to that of the daughter who met death with grief and tears.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:19
verses.text: He then comes to Samuel, another Nazarite of the Lord, who from infancy was brought up in the tabernacle and was clad in a linen ephod, or, as the words are rendered, in linen vestments: he, too, we are told, begot sons without a stain upon his priestly purity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:20
verses.text: He places Boaz and his wife Ruth side by side in his repository, and traces the descent of Jesse and David from them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:21
verses.text: He then points out how David himself, for the price of two hundred foreskins and at the peril of his life, was bedded with the king's daughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:22
verses.text: What shall I say of Solomon, whom he includes in the list of husbands, and represents as a type of the Saviour, maintaining that of him it was written, "Give the king thy judgments, O God, and thy righteousness unto the king's son"? And "To him shall be given of the gold of Sheba, and men shall pray for him continually".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:23
verses.text: Then all at once he makes a jump to Elijah and Elisha, and tells us as a great secret that the spirit of Elijah rested on Elisha.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:24
verses.text: Why he mentioned this he does not say.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:25
verses.text: It can hardly be that he thinks Elijah and Elisha, like the rest, were married men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:26
verses.text: The next step is to Hezekiah, upon whose praises he dwells, and yet (I wonder why) forgets to mention that he said, "Henceforth I will beget children".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:27
verses.text: He relates that Josiah, a righteous man, in whose time the book of Deuteronomy was found in the temple, was instructed by Huldah, wife of Shallum.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:28
verses.text: Daniel also and the three youths are classed by him with the married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:29
verses.text: Suddenly he betakes himself to the Gospel, and adduces Zachariah and Elizabeth, Peter and his father-in-law, and the rest of the Apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:30
verses.text: His inference is thus expressed: "If they idly urge in defence of themselves the plea that the world in its early stage needed to be replenished, let them listen to the words of Paul, 'I desire therefore that the younger widows marry, bear children.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:31
verses.text: ' And 'Marriage is honourable and the bed undefiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:32
verses.text: ' And 'A wife is bound for so long time as her husband liveth; but if the husband be dead, she is free to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:33
verses.text: ' And 'Adam was not beguiled, but the woman being beguiled hath fallen into transgression: but she shall be saved through the child-bearing, if they continue in faith and love and sanctification with sobriety.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:34
verses.text: ' Surely we shall hear no more of the famous Apostolic utterance, 'And they who have wives as though they had them not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:35
verses.text: ' It can hardly be that you will say the reason why he wished them to be married was that some widows had already turned back after Satan: as though virgins never fell and their fall was not more ruinous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:36
verses.text: All this makes it clear that in forbidding to marry, and to eat food which God created for use, you have consciences seared as with a hot iron, and are followers of the Manichaeans".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:37
verses.text: Then comes much more which it would be unprofitable to discuss.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 5:38
verses.text: At last he dashes into rhetoric and apostrophizes virginity thus: "I do you no wrong, Virgin: you have chosen a life of chastity on account of the present distress: you determined on the course in order to be holy in body and spirit: be not proud: you and your married sisters are members of the same Church".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:2
verses.text: I have perhaps explained his position at too great a length, and become tedious to my reader; but I thought it best to draw up in full array against myself all his efforts, and to muster all the forces of the enemy with their squadrons and generals, lest after an early victory there should spring up a series of other engagements.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:3
verses.text: I will not therefore do battle with single foes, nor will I be satisfied with skirmishes in which I meet small detachments of my opponents.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:4
verses.text: The battle must be fought with the whole army of the enemy, and the disorderly rabble, fighting more like brigands than soldiers, must be repulsed by the skill and method of regular warfare.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:5
verses.text: In the front rank I will set the Apostle Paul, and, since he is the bravest of generals, will arm him with his own weapons, that is to say, his own statements.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:6
verses.text: For the Corinthians asked many questions about this matter, and the doctor of the Gentiles and master of the Church gave full replies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:7
verses.text: What he decreed we may regard as the law of Christ speaking in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 6:8
verses.text: At the same time, when we begin to refute the several arguments, I trust the reader will give me his attention even before the Apostle speaks, and will not, in his eagerness to discuss the most weighty points, neglect the premises, and rush at once to the conclusion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:2
verses.text: Among other things the Corinthians asked in their letter whether after embracing the faith of Christ they ought to be unmarried, and for the sake of continence put away their wives, and whether believing virgins were at liberty to marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:3
verses.text: And again, supposing that one of two Gentiles believed on Christ, whether the one that believed should leave the one that believed not? And in case it were allowable to take wives, would the Apostle direct that only Christian wives, or Gentiles also, should be taken? Let us then consider Paul's replies to these inquiries".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:4
verses.text: Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote: It is good for a man not to touch a woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:5
verses.text: But, because of fornications, let each man have his own wife, and let each woman have her own husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:6
verses.text: Let the husband render unto the wife her due: and likewise also the wife unto the husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:7
verses.text: The wife hath not power over her own body, but the husband: And likewise also the husband hath not power over his own body, but the wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:8
verses.text: Defraud ye not one the other, except it be by consent for a season, that ye may give yourselves unto prayer, and may be together again, that Satan tempt you not because of your incontinency.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:9
verses.text: But this I say by way of permission not of commandment.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:10
verses.text: Yet I would that all men were even as I myself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:11
verses.text: Howbeit each man hath his own gift from God, one after this manner, and another after that.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:12
verses.text: But I say to the unmarried and to widows, it is good for them if they abide even as I.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:13
verses.text: But if they have not continency, let them marry: for it is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:14
verses.text: Let us turn back to the chief point of the evidence: "It is good," he says, "for a man not to touch a woman".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:15
verses.text: If it is good not to touch a woman, it is bad to touch one: for there is no opposite to goodness but badness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:16
verses.text: But if it be bad and the evil is pardoned, the reason for the concession is to prevent worse evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:17
verses.text: But surely a thing which is only allowed because there may be something worse has only a slight degree of goodness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:18
verses.text: He would never have added "let each man have his own wife," unless he had previously used the words "but, because of fornications".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:19
verses.text: Do away with fornication, and he will not say "let each man have his own wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:20
verses.text: Just as though one were to lay it down: "It is good to feed on wheaten bread, and to eat the finest wheat flour," and yet to prevent a person pressed by hunger from devouring cow-dung, I may allow him to eat barley.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:21
verses.text: Does it follow that the wheat will not have its peculiar purity, because such an one prefers barley to excrement? That is naturally good which does not admit of comparison with what is bad, and is not eclipsed because something else is preferred.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:22
verses.text: At the same time we must notice the Apostle's prudence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:23
verses.text: He did not say, it is good not to have a wife: but, it is good not to touch a woman: as though there were danger even in the touch: as though he who touched her, would not escape from her who "hunteth for the precious life," who causeth the young man's understanding to fly away".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:24
verses.text: Can a man take fire in his bosom, and his clothes not be burned? Or can one walk upon hot coals, and his feet not be scorched?" As then he who touches fire is instantly burned, so by the mere touch the peculiar nature of man and woman is perceived, and the difference of sex is understood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:25
verses.text: Heathen fables relate howMithras andEricthonius were begotten of the soil, in stone or earth, by raging lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:26
verses.text: Hence it was that our Joseph, because the Egyptian woman wished to touch him, fled from her hands, and, as if he had been bitten by a mad dog and feared the spreading poison, threw away the cloak which she had touched.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:27
verses.text: "But, because of fornications let each man have his own wife, and let each woman have her own husband".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:28
verses.text: He did not say, because of fornication let each man marry a wife: otherwise by this excuse he would have thrown the reins to lust, and whenever a man's wife died, he would have to marry another to prevent fornication, but "have his own wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:29
verses.text: Let him he says have and use his own wife, whom he had before he became a believer, and whom it would have been good not to touch, and, when once he became a follower of Christ, to know only as a sister, not as a wife unless fornication should make it excusable to touch her.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:30
verses.text: "The wife hath not power over her own body, but the husband: and likewise also the husband hath not power over his own body, but the wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:31
verses.text: The whole question here concerns those who are married men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:32
verses.text: Is it lawful for them to do what our Lord forbade in the Gospel, and to put away their wives? Whence it is that the Apostle says, "It is good for a man not to touch a woman".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:33
verses.text: But inasmuch as he who is once married has no power to abstain except by mutual consent, and may not reject an unoffending partner, let the husband render unto the wife her due.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:34
verses.text: He bound himself voluntarily that he might be under compulsion to render it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:35
verses.text: "Defraud ye not one the other, except it be by consent for a season, that ye may give yourselves unto prayer".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:36
verses.text: What, I pray you, is the quality of that good thing which hinders prayer? which does not allow the body of Christ to be received? So long as I do the husband's part, I fail in continency.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:37
verses.text: The same Apostle in another place commands us to pray always.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:38
verses.text: If we are to pray always, it follows that we must never be in the bondage of wedlock, for as often as I render my wife her due, I cannot pray.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:39
verses.text: The Apostle Peter had experience of the bonds of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:40
verses.text: See how he fashions the Church, and what lesson he teaches Christians: "Ye husbands in like manner dwell with your wives according to knowledge, giving honour unto the woman, as unto the weaker vessel, as being also joint-heirs of the grace of life; to the end that your prayers be not hindered".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:41
verses.text: Observe that, as S.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:42
verses.text: Paul before, because in both cases the spirit is the same, so S.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:43
verses.text: Peter now, says that prayers are hindered by the performance of marriage duty.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:44
verses.text: When he says "likewise," he challenges the husbands to imitate their wives, because he has already given them commandment: "beholding your chaste conversation coupled with fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:45
verses.text: Whose adorning let it not be the outward adorning of plaiting the hair, and of wearing jewels of gold, or of putting on apparel: but let it be the hidden man of the heart, in the incorruptible apparel of a meek and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:46
verses.text: You see what kind of wedlock he enjoins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:47
verses.text: Husbands and wives are to dwell together according to knowledge, so that they may know what God wishes and desires, and give honour to the weak vessel, woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:48
verses.text: If we abstain from intercourse, we give honour to our wives: if we do not abstain, it is clear that insult is the opposite of honour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:49
verses.text: He also tells the wives to let their husbands "see their chaste behaviour, and the hidden man of the heart, in the incorruptible apparel of a meek and quiet spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:50
verses.text: Words truly worthy of an apostle, and of Christ's rock! He lays down the law for husbands and wives, condemns outward ornament, while he praises continence, which is the ornament of the inner man, as seen in the incorruptible apparel of a meek and quiet spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:51
verses.text: In effect he says this: Since your outer man is corrupt, and you have ceased to possess the blessing of incorruption characteristic of virgins, at least imitate the incorruption of the spirit by subsequent abstinence, and what you cannot show in the body exhibit in the mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 7:52
verses.text: For these are the riches, and these the ornaments of your union, which Christ seeks.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:2
verses.text: The words which follow, "that ye may give yourselves unto prayer, and may be together again," might lead one to suppose that the Apostle was expressing a wish and not making a concession because of the danger of a greater fall.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:3
verses.text: He therefore at once adds, "lest Satan tempt you for your incontinency".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:4
verses.text: It is a fine permission which is conveyed in the words "be together again".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:5
verses.text: What it was that he blushed to call by its own name, and thought only better than a temptation of Satan and the effect of incontinence, we take trouble to discuss as if it were obscure, although he has explained his meaning by saying, "this I say by way of permission, not by way of command".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:6
verses.text: And do we still hesitate to speak of marriage as a concession to weakness, not a thing commanded, as though second and third marriages were not allowed on the same ground, as though the doors of the Church were not opened by repentance even to fornicators, and what is more, to the incestuous? Take the case of the man who outraged his step-mother.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:7
verses.text: Does not the Apostle, after delivering him, in his first Epistle to the Corinthians, to Satan for the destruction of the flesh that his spirit might be saved, in the second Epistle take the offender back and strive to prevent a brother from being swallowed up by overmuch grief.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:8
verses.text: The Apostle's wish is one thing, his pardon another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:9
verses.text: If a wish be expressed, it confers a right; if a thing is only called pardonable, we are wrong in using it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:10
verses.text: If you wish to know the Apostle's real mind, you must take in what follows: "but I would that all men were as I am".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:11
verses.text: Happy is the man who is like Paul! Fortunate is he who attends to the Apostle's command, not to his concession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:12
verses.text: This, says he, I wish, this I desire that ye be imitators of me, as I also am of Christ, who was a Virgin born of a Virgin, uncorrupt of her who was uncorrupt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:13
verses.text: We, because we are men, cannot imitate our Lord's nativity; but we may at least imitate His life.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:14
verses.text: The former was the blessed prerogative of divinity, the latter belongs to our human condition and is part of human effort.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:15
verses.text: I would that all men were like me, that while they are like me, they may also become like Christ, to whom I am like.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:16
verses.text: For"he that believeth in Christ ought himself also to walk even as He walked".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:17
verses.text: "Howbeit each man hath his own gift from God, one after this manner, and another after that".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:18
verses.text: What I wish, he says, is clear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:19
verses.text: But since in the Church there is a diversity of gifts, I acquiesce in marriage, lest I should seem to condemn nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:20
verses.text: At the same time consider, that the gift of virginity is one, that of marriage, another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:21
verses.text: For were the reward the same for the married and for virgins, he would never after enjoining continence have said:"Each man hath his own gift from God, one after this manner, and another after that".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:22
verses.text: Where there is a distinction in one particular, there is a diversity also in other points.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:23
verses.text: I grant that even marriage is a gift of God, but between gift and gift there is great diversity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:24
verses.text: In fact the Apostle himself speaking of the same person who had repented of his incestuous conduct, says:"so that contrariwise ye should rather forgive him and comfort him, and to whom ye forgive anything, I forgive also".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:25
verses.text: And that we might not think a man's gift contemptible, he added,"for what I also have forgiven, if I have forgiven anything, for your sakes have I forgiven it, in the presence of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:26
verses.text: There is diversity in the gifts of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:27
verses.text: Hence it is that by way of type Joseph has a coat of many colours.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:28
verses.text: And in the forty-fifth psalm we read,"at thy right hand doth stand the queen in a vesture of gold wrought about with divers colours".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 8:29
verses.text: And the Apostle Peter says,"as heirs together of the manifold grace of God," where the more expressive Greek word ποικίλης, i-e:, varied, is used.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:2
verses.text: Then come the words"But I say to the unmarried and to widows, it is good for them if they abide even as I.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:3
verses.text: But if they have not continency, let them marry: for it is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:4
verses.text: Having conceded to married persons the enjoyment of wedlock and pointed out his own wishes, he passes on to the unmarried and to widows, sets before them his own practice for imitation, and calls them happy if they so abide.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:5
verses.text: "But if they have not continency, let them marry," just as he said before "But because of fornications," and "Lest Satan tempt you, because of your incontinency".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:6
verses.text: And he gives a reason for saying "If they have not continency, let them marry," viz.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:7
verses.text: "It is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:8
verses.text: The reason why it is better to marry is that it is worse to burn.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:9
verses.text: Let burning lust be absent, and he will not say it is better to marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:10
verses.text: The word better always implies a comparison with something worse, not a thing absolutely good and incapable of comparison.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:11
verses.text: It is as though he said, it is better to have one eye than neither, it is better to stand on one foot and to support the rest of the body with a stick, than to crawl with broken legs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:12
verses.text: What do you say, Apostle? I do not believe you when you say "Though I be rude in speech, yet am I not in knowledge".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:13
verses.text: As humility is the source of the sayings "For I am not worthy to be called an Apostle," and "To me who am the least of the Apostles," and "As to one born out of due time," so here also we have an utterance of humility.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:14
verses.text: You know the meaning of language, or you would not quote Epimenides, Menander, and Aratus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:15
verses.text: When you are discussing continence and virginity you say, "It is good for a man not to touch a woman".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:16
verses.text: And, "It is good for them if they abide even as I".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:17
verses.text: And, "I think that this is good by reason of the present distress".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:18
verses.text: And, "That it is good for a man so to be".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:19
verses.text: When you come to marriage, you do not say it is good to marry, because you cannot then add "than to burn;" but you say, "It is better to marry than to burn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:20
verses.text: If marriage in itself be good, do not compare it with fire, but simply say "It is good to marry".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:21
verses.text: I suspect the goodness of that thing which is forced into the position of being only the lesser of two evils.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 9:22
verses.text: What I want is not a smaller evil, but a thing absolutely good.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:2
verses.text: So far the first section has been explained.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:3
verses.text: Let us now come to those which follow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:4
verses.text: "But unto the married I give charge, yea not I, but the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:5
verses.text: That the wife depart not from her husband (but and if she depart, let her remain unmarried, or else be reconciled to her husband): and that the husband leave not his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:6
verses.text: But to the rest say I, not the Lord: If any brother hath an unbelieving wife, and she is content to dwell with him, let him not leave her," and so on to the words "As God hath called each, so let him walk.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:7
verses.text: And so ordain I in all the churches".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:8
verses.text: This passage has no bearing on our present controversy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:9
verses.text: For he ordains, according to the mind of the Lord, that excepting the cause of fornication, a wife must not be put away, and that a wife who has been put away, may not, so long as her husband lives, be married to another, or at all events that her duty is to be reconciled to her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:10
verses.text: But in the case of those who are already married at the time of conversion, that is to say, supposing one of the two were a believer, he enjoins that the believer shall not put away the unbeliever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:11
verses.text: And after stating his reason, viz.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:12
verses.text: , that the unbeliever who is unwilling to leave the believer becomes thereby a candidate for the faith, he commands, on the other hand, that if the unbeliever reject the faithful one on account of the faith of Christ, the believer ought to depart, lest husband or wife be preferred to Christ, in comparison with Whom we must hold even life itself cheap.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:13
verses.text: Yet at the present day many women despising the Apostle's command, are joined to heathen husbands, and prostitute the temples of Christ to idols.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:14
verses.text: They do not understand that they are part of His body though indeed they are His ribs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:15
verses.text: The Apostle is lenient to the union of unbelievers, who having (believing) husbands, afterwards come to believe in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:16
verses.text: He does not extend his indulgence to those women who, although Christians, have been married to heathen husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:17
verses.text: To these he elsewhere says, "Be not unequally yoked with unbelievers: for what fellowship have righteousness and iniquity? or what communion hath light with darkness? And what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what portion hath a believer with an unbeliever? And what agreement hath a temple of God with idols? For we are a temple of the living God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:18
verses.text: Although I know that crowds of matrons will be furious against me: although I know that just as they have shamelessly despised the Lord, so they will rave at me who am but a flea and the least of Christians: yet I will speak out what I think.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:19
verses.text: I will say what the Apostle has taught me, that they are not on the side of righteousness, but of iniquity: not of light, but of darkness: that they do not belong to Christ, but to Belial: that they are not temples of the living God, but shrines and idols of the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:20
verses.text: And, if you wish to see more clearly how utterly unlawful it is for a Christian woman to marry a Gentile, consider what the same Apostle says, "A wife is bound for so long time as her husband liveth: but if the husband be dead, she is free to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord," that is, to a Christian.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:21
verses.text: He who allows second and third marriages in the Lord, forbids first marriages with a Gentile.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:22
verses.text: Whence Abraham also makes his servant swear upon his thigh, that is, on Christ, Who was to spring from his seed, that he would not bring an alien-born as a wife for his son Isaac.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:23
verses.text: And Ezra checked an offence of this kind against God by making his countrymen put away their wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:24
verses.text: And the prophet Malachi thus speaks, "Judah hath dealt treacherously, and an abomination is committed in Israel and in Jerusalem; for Judah hath profaned the holiness of the Lord which he loveth, and hath married the daughter of a strange god.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:25
verses.text: The Lord will cut off the man that doeth this, him that teacheth and him that learneth, out of the tents of Jacob, and him that offers an offering unto the Lord of hosts".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 10:26
verses.text: I have said this that they who compare marriage with virginity, may at least know that such marriages as these are on a lower level than digamy and trigamy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:2
verses.text: In the above discussion the Apostle has taught that the believer ought not to depart from the unbeliever, but remain in marriage as the faith found them, and that each man whether married or single should continue as he was when baptized into Christ; and then he suddenly introduces the metaphors of circumcision and uncircumcision, of bond and free, and under those metaphors treats of the married and unmarried.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:3
verses.text: "Was any man called being circumcised? let him not become uncircumcised.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:4
verses.text: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing: but the keeping of the commandments of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:5
verses.text: Let each man abide in that calling wherein he was called.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:6
verses.text: Wast thou called being a bondservant? Care not for it: but even if thou canst become free, use it rather.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:7
verses.text: For he that was called in the Lord being a bondservant, is the Lord's freedman; likewise he that was called, being free, is Christ's bondservant.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:8
verses.text: Ye were bought with a price; become not bondservants of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:9
verses.text: Brethren, let each man, wherein he was called, therein abide with God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:10
verses.text: Some, I suppose, will find fault with the Apostle's way of reasoning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:11
verses.text: I would therefore ask first, What we are to infer from his suddenly passing in a discussion concerning husbands and wives to a comparison of Jew and Gentile, bond and free, and then returning, when this point is settled, to the question about virgins, and telling us "Concerning virgins I have no commandment from the Lord"; what has a comparison of Jew and Gentile, bond and free, to do with wedlock and virginity? In the next place, how are we to understand the words "Hath any been called in uncircumcision, let him not be circumcised"? Can a man who has lost his foreskin restore it again at his pleasure? Then, in what sense are we to explain "For he that was called in the Lord, being a bondservant, is the Lord's freedman: likewise he that was called, being free, is Christ's bondservant".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:12
verses.text: Fourthly, how is it that he who commanded servants to obey their masters according to the flesh, now says, "Become not bondservants of men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:13
verses.text: Lastly, how are we to connect with slavery, or with circumcision, his saying "Brethren, let each man, wherein he was called, therein abide with God," which even contradicts his previous opinion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:14
verses.text: We heard him say "Become not bondservants of men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:15
verses.text: How can we then possibly abide in that vocation wherein we were called, when many at the time they became believers had masters according to the flesh, whose bondservants they are now forbidden to be? Moreover, what has the argument about our abiding in the vocation wherein we were called, to do with circumcision? for in another place the same Apostle cries aloud "Behold I Paul tell you that, if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing"? We must conclude, therefore, that a higher meaning should be given to circumcision and uncircumcision, bond and free, and that these words must be taken in close connection with what has gone before.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:16
verses.text: "Was anyone called being circumcised? let him not become uncircumcised".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:17
verses.text: If, he says, at the time you were called and became a believer in Christ, if I say, you were called being circumcised from a wife, that is, unmarried, do not marry a wife, that is, do not become uncircumcised, lest you lay upon the freedom of circumcision and chastity the burden of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:18
verses.text: Again, if anyone was called in uncircumcision, let him not be circumcised.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:19
verses.text: You had a wife, he says, when you believed: do not think the faith of Christ a reason for disagreement, because God called us in peace".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:20
verses.text: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing; but the keeping of the commandments of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:21
verses.text: For neither celibacy nor marriage availeth anything without works, since even faith, which is specially characteristic of Christians, if it have not works, is said to be dead, and vestal virgins and Juno's widows might upon these terms be numbered with the saints.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:22
verses.text: "Let each man in the vocation wherein he was called, therein abide".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:23
verses.text: Whether he had, or had not, a wife when he believed, let him remain in that condition in which he was when called.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:24
verses.text: Accordingly he does not so strongly urge virgins to be married, as forbid divorce.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:25
verses.text: And as he debars those who have wives from putting them away, so he cuts off from virgins the power of being married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:26
verses.text: "Thou wast called being a slave, heed it not; but even if thou canst become free, use it rather".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:27
verses.text: Even if you have, he says, a wife, and are bound to her, and pay her due, and have not power over your own body; or if, to speak more clearly, you are the bondservant of your wife, be not sad upon that account, nor sigh for the loss of your virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:28
verses.text: But even if you can find some causes of discord, do not, for the sake of thoroughly enjoying the liberty of chastity, seek your own welfare by destroying another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:29
verses.text: Keep your wife awhile, and do not go too fast for her lagging footsteps: wait till she follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:30
verses.text: If you are patient, your spouse will become a sister, "For he that was called in the Lord, being a bondservant, is the Lord's freedman: likewise, he that was called being free, is Christ's bondservant".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:31
verses.text: He gives his reasons for not wishing wives to be forsaken.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:32
verses.text: He therefore says, I command that Gentiles who believe on Christ do not abandon the married state in which they were before embracing the faith: for he who had a wife when he became a believer, is not so strictly devoted to the service of God as virgins and unmarried persons.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:33
verses.text: But, in a manner, he has more freedom, and the reins of his bondage are relaxed; and, while he is the bondservant of a wife, he is, so to speak, the freedman of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:34
verses.text: Moreover, he who when called by the Lord had not a wife and was free from the bondage of wedlock, he is truly Christ's bondservant.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:35
verses.text: What happiness to be the bondservant, not of a wife but of Christ, to serve not the flesh, but the spirit!"For he who is joined unto the Lord is one spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:36
verses.text: There was some fear that by saying "Wast thou called being a bondservant? Care not for it: but, even if thou canst become free, use it rather," he might seem to have flouted continence, and to have given us up to the slavery of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:37
verses.text: He therefore makes a remark which removes all cavil: "Ye were bought with a price, become not servants of men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:38
verses.text: We have been redeemed with the most precious blood of Christ: the Lamb was slain for us, and having been sprinkled with hyssop and the warm drops of His blood, we have rejected poisonous pleasure.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 11:39
verses.text: Why do we at whose baptism Pharaoh died and all his host was drowned, again turn back in our hearts to Egypt, and after the manna, angels' food, sigh for the garlic and the onions and the cucumbers, and Pharaoh's meat?.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:2
verses.text: Having discussed marriage and continency he at length comes to virginity and says"Now concerning virgins I have no commandment of the Lord: but I give my judgement, as one that hath obtained mercy of the Lord to be faithful.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:3
verses.text: I think therefore that this is good by reason of the present distress, namely, that it is good for a man to be as he is".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:4
verses.text: Here our opponent goes utterly wild with exultation: this is his strongest battering-ram with which he shakes the wall of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:5
verses.text: "See," says he, "the Apostle confesses that as regards virgins he has no commandment of the Lord, and he who had with authority laid down the law respecting husbands and wives, does not dare to command what the Lord has not enjoined.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:6
verses.text: And rightly too.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:7
verses.text: For what is enjoined is commanded, what is commanded must be done, and that which must be done implies punishment if it be not done.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:8
verses.text: For it is useless to order a thing to be done and yet leave the individual free to do it or not do it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:9
verses.text: If the Lord had commanded virginity He would have seemed to condemn marriage, and to do away with the seed-plot of mankind, of which virginity itself is a growth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:10
verses.text: If He had cut off the root, how was He to expect fruit? If the foundations were not first laid, how was He to build the edifice, and put on the roof to cover all! Excavators toil hard to remove mountains; the bowels of the earth are pierced in the search for gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:11
verses.text: And, when the tiny particles, first by the blast of the furnace, then by the hand of the cunning workman have been fashioned into an ornament, men do not call him blessed who has separated the gold from the dross, but him who wears the beautiful gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:12
verses.text: Do not marvel then if, placed as we are, amid temptations of the flesh and incentives to vice, the angelic life be not exacted of us, but merely recommended.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:13
verses.text: If advice be given, a man is free to proffer obedience; if there be a command, he is a servant bound to compliance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:14
verses.text: "I have no commandment," he says, "of the Lord: but I give my judgement, as one that hath obtained mercy of the Lord to be faithful".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:15
verses.text: If you have no commandment of the Lord, how dare you give judgement without orders? The Apostle will reply: Do you wish me to give orders where the Lord has offered a favour rather than laid down a law? The great Creator and Fashioner, knowing the weakness of the vessel which he made, left virginity open to those whom He addressed; and shall I, the teacher of the Gentiles, who have become all things to all men that I might gain all, shall I lay upon the necks of weak believers from the very first the burden of perpetual chastity? Let thembegin with short periods of release from the marriage bond, and give themselves unto prayer, that when they have tasted the sweets of chastity they may desire the perpetual possession of that wherewith they were temporarily delighted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:16
verses.text: The Lord, when tempted by the Pharisees, and asked whether according to the law of Moses it was permitted to put away a wife, forbade the practice altogether.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:17
verses.text: After weighing His words the disciples said to Him:"If the case of the man is so with his wife, it is not expedient to marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:18
verses.text: But He said unto them, all men cannot receive this saying, but they to whom it is given.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:19
verses.text: For there are eunuchs, which were so born from their mother's womb: and there are eunuchs, which were made eunuchs by men: and there are eunuchs, which made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:20
verses.text: He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:21
verses.text: The reason is plain why the Apostle said, "concerning virgins I have no commandment of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:22
verses.text: Surely; because the Lord had previously said "All men cannot receive the word, but they to whom it is given," and "He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:23
verses.text: The Master of the Christian race offers the reward, invites candidates to the course, holds in His hand the prize of virginity, points to the fountain of purity, and cries aloud"If any man thirst, let him come unto me and drink".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:24
verses.text: "He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:25
verses.text: He does not say, you must drink, you must run, willing or unwilling: but whoever is willing and able to run and to drink, he shall conquer, he shall be satisfied.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:26
verses.text: And therefore Christ loves virgins more than others, because they willingly give what was not commanded them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:27
verses.text: And it indicates greater grace to offer what you are not bound to give, than to render what is exacted of you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:28
verses.text: The apostles, contemplating the burden of a wife, exclaimed, "If the case of the man is so with his wife, it is not expedient to marry".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:29
verses.text: Our Lord thought well of their view.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:30
verses.text: You rightly think, said He, that it is not expedient for a man who is hastening to the kingdom of heaven to take a wife: but it is a hard matter, and all men do not receive the saying, but they to whom it has been given.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:31
verses.text: Some are eunuchs by nature, others by the violence of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:32
verses.text: Those eunuchs please Me who are such not of necessity, but of free choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:33
verses.text: Willingly do I take them into my bosom who have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake, and in order to worship Me have renounced the condition of their birth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:34
verses.text: We must now explain the words, "Those who have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:35
verses.text: If they who have made themselves eunuchs have the reward of the kingdom of heaven, it follows that they who have not made themselves such cannot be placed with those who have.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:36
verses.text: He who is able, he says, to receive it, let him receive it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:37
verses.text: It is a mark of great faith and of great virtue, to be the pure temple of God, to offer oneself a whole burnt-offering, and, according to the same apostle, to be holy both in body and in spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:38
verses.text: These are the eunuchs, who thinking themselves dry trees because of their impotence, hear by the mouth ofIsaiah that they have a place prepared in heaven for sons and daughters.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:39
verses.text: Their type isEbed-melech the eunuch in Jeremiah, and the eunuch of Queen Candace in theActs of the Apostles, who on account of the strength of his faith gained the name of a man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:40
verses.text: These are they to whom Clement, who was the successor of the Apostle Peter, and of whom the Apostle Paul makes mention, wrote letters, directing almost the whole of his discourse to the subject of virgin purity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:41
verses.text: After them there is a long series of apostolic men, martyrs, and men illustrious no less for holiness than for eloquence, with whom we may very easily become acquainted through their own writings".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:42
verses.text: I think, therefore," he says, "that this is good for the present distress".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:43
verses.text: What is this distress which, in contempt of the marriage tie, longs for the liberty of virginity?"Woe unto them that are with child and to them that give suck in those days".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:44
verses.text: We have not here a condemnation of harlots and brothels, of whose damnation there is no doubt, but of the swelling womb, and wailing infancy, the fruit as well as the work of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:45
verses.text: "For it is good for a man so to be".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:46
verses.text: If it is good for a man so to be, it is bad for a man not so to be".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:47
verses.text: Art thou bound unto a wife? Seek not to be loosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:48
verses.text: Art thou loosed from a wife? Seek not a wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:49
verses.text: Each one of us has his appointed bounds; let me have what is mine, and keep your own.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:50
verses.text: If thou art bound to a wife, give her not a bill of divorce.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:51
verses.text: If I am loosed from a wife, I will not seek a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:52
verses.text: As I do not dissolve marriages once contracted: so you should not bind what is loosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:53
verses.text: And at the same time the meaning of the words must be taken into account.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:54
verses.text: He who has a wife is regarded as a debtor, and is said to be uncircumcised, to be the servant of his wife, and like bad servants to be bound.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 12:55
verses.text: But he who has no wife, in the first place owes no man anything, then is circumcised, thirdly is free, lastly, is loosed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:2
verses.text: Let us run through the remaining points, for our author is so voluminous that we cannot linger over every detail.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:3
verses.text: "But and if thou marry, thou hast not sinned".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:4
verses.text: It is one thing not to sin, another to do good.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:5
verses.text: "And if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:6
verses.text: Not that virgin who has once for all dedicated herself to the service of God: for, should one of these marry, she will have damnation, because she has made of no account her first faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:7
verses.text: But, if our adversary objects that this saying relates to widows, we reply that it applies with still greater force to virgins, since marriage is forbidden even to widows whose previous marriage had been lawful.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:8
verses.text: For virgins who marry after consecration are rather incestuous than adulterous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:9
verses.text: And, for fear he should by saying, "And if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned," again stimulate the unmarried to be married, he immediately checks himself, and by introducing another consideration, invalidates his previous concession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:10
verses.text: "Yet," says he, "such shall have tribulation in the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:11
verses.text: Who are they who shall have tribulation in the flesh? They to whom he had before indulgently said "But and if thou marry, thou hast not sinned; and if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:12
verses.text: Yet such shall have tribulation in the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:13
verses.text: We in our inexperience thought that marriage had at least the joys of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:14
verses.text: But if they who are married have tribulation even in the flesh, which is imagined to be the sole source of their pleasure, what else is there to marry for, when in the spirit, and in the mind, and in the flesh itself there is tribulation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:15
verses.text: "But I would spare you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:16
verses.text: Thus, he says, I allege tribulation as a motive, as though there were not greater obligations to refrain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:17
verses.text: "But this I say, brethren, the time is shortened, that henceforth both those that have wives may be as though they had none".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:18
verses.text: I am by no means now discussing virgins, of whose happiness no one entertains a doubt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:19
verses.text: I am coming to the married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:20
verses.text: The time is short, the Lord is at hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:21
verses.text: Even though we lived nine hundred years, as did men of old, yet we ought to think that short which must one day have an end, and cease to be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:22
verses.text: But, as things are, and it is not so much the joy as the tribulation of marriage that is short, why do we take wives whom we shall soon be compelled to lose?"And those that weep, and those that rejoice, and those that buy, and those that use the world, as though they wept not, as though they rejoiced not, as though they bought not, as though they did not use the world: for the fashion of this world passeth away".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:23
verses.text: If the world, which comprehends all things, passes away, yea if the fashion and intercourse of the world vanishes like the clouds, amongst the other works of the world, marriage too will vanish away.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:24
verses.text: For after the resurrection there will be no wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:25
verses.text: But if death be the end of marriage, why do we not voluntarily embrace the inevitable? And why do we not, encouraged by the hope of the reward, offer to God that which must be wrung from us against our will.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:26
verses.text: "He that is unmarried is careful for the things of the Lord, how he may please the Lord: but he that is married is careful for the things of the world, how he may please his wife, and is divided".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:27
verses.text: Let us look at the difference between the cares of the virgin, and those of the married man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:28
verses.text: The virgin longs to please the Lord, the husband to please his wife, and that he may please her he is careful for the things of the world, which will of course pass away with the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:29
verses.text: "And he is divided," that is to say, is distracted with manifold cares and miseries.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:30
verses.text: This is not the place to describe the difficulties of marriage, and to revel in rhetorical commonplaces.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:31
verses.text: I think I delivered myself fully as regards this point in my argument againstHelvidius, and in the book which I addressed toEustochium.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:32
verses.text: At all eventsTertullian, while still a young man, gave himself full play with this subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:33
verses.text: And my teacher,Gregory of Nazianzus, discussed virginity and marriage in some Greek verses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:34
verses.text: I now briefly beg my reader to note that in the Latin manuscripts we have the reading "there is a difference also between the virgin and the wife".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:35
verses.text: The words, it is true, have a meaning of their own, and have by me, as well as by others, been so explained as showing the bearing of the passage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:36
verses.text: Yet they lack apostolic authority, since the Apostle's words are as we have translated them—"He is careful for the things of the world, how he may please his wife, and he is divided".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:37
verses.text: Having laid down this, he passes to the virgins and the continent, and says "The woman that is unmarried and a virgin thinks of the things of the Lord, that she may be holy in body and in spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:38
verses.text: Not every unmarried woman is also a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:39
verses.text: But every virgin is of course unmarried.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:40
verses.text: It may be, that regard for elegance of expression led him to repeat the same idea by means of another word and speak of "a woman unmarried and a virgin"; or at least he may have wished to give to "unmarried" the definite meaning of "virgin," so that we might not suppose him to include harlots, united to no one by the fixed bonds of wedlock, among the "unmarried".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:41
verses.text: Of what, then, does she that is unmarried and a virgin think? "The things of the Lord, that she may be holy both in body and in spirit".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:42
verses.text: Supposing there were nothing else, and that no greater reward followed virginity, this would be motive enough for her choice, to think of the things of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:43
verses.text: But he immediately points out the contents of her thought—that she may be holy both in body and spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:44
verses.text: For there are virgins in the flesh, not in the spirit, whose body is intact, their soul corrupt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:45
verses.text: But that virgin is a sacrifice to Christ, whose mind has not been defiled by thought, nor her flesh by lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:46
verses.text: On the other hand, she who is married thinks of the things of the world, how she may please her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:47
verses.text: Just as the man who has a wife is anxious for the things of the world, how he may please his wife, so the married woman thinks of the things of the world, how she may please her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:48
verses.text: But we are not of this world, which lieth in wickedness, the fashion of which passeth away, and concerning which the Lord said to the Apostles, "If ye were of the world, the world would love its own".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:49
