verses.text: And lest perchance someone might suppose that he was laying the heavy burden of chastity on unwilling shoulders, he at once adds his reasons for persuading to it, and says:"And this I say for your profit; not that I may cast a snare upon you, but for that which is seemly, and that ye may attend upon the Lord without distraction".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:50
verses.text: The Latin words do not convey the meaning of the Greek.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:51
verses.text: What words shall we use to render Πρὸς τὸ εὔσχημον κὰι εὐπρόσεδρον τῷ Κυρί& 251· ἀπερισπάστως́̈ The difficulty of translation accounts for the fact that the clause is completely wanting in Latin manuscripts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:52
verses.text: Let us, however, use the passage as we have translated it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:53
verses.text: The Apostle does not lay a snare upon us, nor does he compel us to be what we do not wish to be; but he gives his advice as to what is fair and seemly, he would have us attend upon the Lord and ever be anxious about that service, and await the Lord's will, so that like active and well-armed soldiers we may obey orders, and may do so without distraction, which, according toEcclesiastes, is given to the men of this world that they may be exercised thereby.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:54
verses.text: But if anyone considers that his virgin, that is, his flesh, is wanton and boiling with lust, and cannot be bridled, and he must do one of two things, either take a wife or fall, let him do what he will, he does not sin if he marry.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:55
verses.text: Let him do, he says, what he will, not what he ought.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:56
verses.text: He does not sin if he marry a wife; yet, he does not well if he marry: "But he that standeth stedfast in his heart, having no necessity, but hath power as touching his own will, and hath determined this in his own heart, to keep his own virgin, shall do well.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:57
verses.text: So then both he that giveth his own virgin in marriage doeth well; and he that giveth her not in marriage shall do better".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:58
verses.text: With marked propriety he had previously said "He who marries a wife does not sin": here he tells us "He that keepeth his own virgin doeth well".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:59
verses.text: But it is one thing not to sin, another to do well".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:60
verses.text: Depart from evil," he says, "and do good".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:61
verses.text: The former we forsake, the latter we follow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:62
verses.text: In this last lies perfection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:63
verses.text: But whereas he says "and he that giveth his virgin in marriage doeth well," it might be supposed that our remark does not hold good; he therefore forthwith detracts from this seeming good and puts it in the shade by comparing it with another, and saying, "and he that giveth her not in marriage shall do better".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:64
verses.text: If he had not intended to draw the inference of doing better, he would never have previously referred to doing well.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:65
verses.text: But where there is something good and something better, the reward is not in both cases the same, and where the reward is not one and the same, there of course the gifts are different.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 13:66
verses.text: The difference, then, between marriage and virginity is as great as that between not sinning and doing well; nay rather, to speak less harshly, as great as between good and better.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:2
verses.text: He has ended his discussion of wedlock and virginity, and has carefully steered between the two precepts without turning to the right hand or to the left.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:3
verses.text: He has followed the royal road and fulfilled the command not to be righteous over much.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:4
verses.text: Now again he compares monogamy with digamy, and as he had subordinated marriage to virginity, so he makes second marriages inferior to first, and says, "A wife is bound for so long time as her husband liveth; but if the husband be dead, she is free to be married to whom she will; only in the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:5
verses.text: But she is happier if she abide as she is, after my judgement: and I think that I also have the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:6
verses.text: He allows second marriages, but to such persons as wish for them and are not able to contain; lest, having "waxed wanton against Christ," they desire to marry, "having condemnation, because they have rejected their first faith;" and he makes the concession because many had already turned aside after Satan".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:7
verses.text: But," says he, "they will be happier if they abide as they are," and he immediately adds the weight of Apostolic authority, "after my judgement".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:8
verses.text: And that an Apostle's authority might not, like that of an ordinary man, be without weight, he added, "and I think that I also have the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:9
verses.text: When he incites to continence, it is not by the judgement or spirit of man, but by the judgement and Spirit of God; when, however, he grants the indulgence of marriage, he does not mention the Spirit of God, but weighs his judgement with wisdom, and adapts the severity of the strain to the weakness of the individual.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:10
verses.text: In this sense we must take the whole of the following passage: "For the woman that hath a husband is bound by law to the husband while he liveth; but if the husband die, she is discharged from the law of the husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:11
verses.text: So then if, while the husband liveth, she be joined to another man, she shall be called an adulteress: but if the husband die, she is free from the law, so that she is no adulteress, though she be joined to another man".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:12
verses.text: And similarly the words to Timothy,"I desire therefore that the younger widows marry, bear children, rule the household, give none occasion to the adversary for reviling: for already some are turned aside after Satan," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:13
verses.text: For as on account of the danger of fornication he allows virgins to marry, and makes that excusable which in itself is not desirable, so to avoid this same fornication, he allows second marriages to widows.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:14
verses.text: For it is better to know a single husband, though he be a second or third, than to have many paramours: that is, it is more tolerable for a woman to prostitute herself to one man than to many.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:15
verses.text: At all events this is so if the Samaritan woman in John's Gospel who said she had her sixth husband was reproved by the Lord because he was not her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:16
verses.text: For where there are more husbands than one the proper idea of a husband, who is a single person, is destroyed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:17
verses.text: At the beginning one rib was turned into one wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:18
verses.text: "And they two," he says, "shall be one flesh": not three, or four; otherwise, how can they be any longer two, if they are several.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:19
verses.text: Lamech, a man of blood and a murderer, was the first who divided one flesh between two wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:20
verses.text: Fratricide and digamy were abolished by the same punishment—that of the deluge.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:21
verses.text: The one was avenged seven times, the other seventy times seven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:22
verses.text: The guilt is as widely different as are the numbers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:23
verses.text: What the holiness of second marriage is, appears from this—that a person twice married cannot be enrolled in the ranks of the clergy, and so the Apostle tells Timothy, "Let none be enrolled as a widow under threescore years old, having been the wife of one man".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:24
verses.text: The whole command concerns those widows who are supported on the alms of the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:25
verses.text: The age is therefore limited, so that those only may receive the food of the poor who can no longer work.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:26
verses.text: And at the same time, consider that she who has had two husbands, even though she be a widow, decrepit, and in want, is not a worthy recipient of the Church's funds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 14:27
verses.text: But if she be deprived of the bread of charity, how much more is she deprived of that bread which cometh down from heaven, and of which if a man eat unworthily, he shall be guilty of outrage offered to the body and the blood of Christ?.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:2
verses.text: The passages, however, which I have adduced in support of my position and in which it is permitted to widows, if they so desire, to marry again, are interpreted by some concerning those widows who had lost their husbands and were found in that condition when they became Christians.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:3
verses.text: For, supposing a person baptized and her husband dead, it would not be consistent if the Apostle were to bid her marry another, when he enjoins even those who have wives to be as though they had them not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:4
verses.text: And this is why the number of wives which a man may take is not defined, because when Christian baptism has been received, even though a third or a fourth wife has been taken, she is reckoned as the first.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:5
verses.text: Otherwise, if, after baptism and after the death of a first husband, a second is taken why should not a sixth after the death of the second, third, fourth, and fifth, and so on? For it is possible, that through some strange misfortune, or by the judgement of God cutting short repeated marriages, a young woman may have several husbands, while an old woman may be left a widow by her first husband in extreme age.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:6
verses.text: The first Adam was married once: the second was unmarried.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:7
verses.text: Let the supporters of second marriages shew us as their leader a third Adam who was twice married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:8
verses.text: But granted that Paul allowed second marriages: upon the same grounds it follows that he allows even third and fourth marriages, or a woman may marry as often as her husband dies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:9
verses.text: The Apostle was forced to choose many things which he did not like.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:10
verses.text: He circumcised Timothy, and shaved his own head, practised going barefoot, let his hair grow long, and cut it at Cenchrea.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:11
verses.text: And he had certainly chastised the Galatians, and blamed Peter because for the sake of Jewish observances he separated himself from the Gentiles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:12
verses.text: As then in other points connected with the discipline of the Church he was a Jew to Jews, a Gentile to Gentiles, and was made all things to all men, that he might gain all: so too he allowed second marriages to incontinent persons, and did not limit the number of marriages, in order that women, although they saw themselves permitted to take a second husband, in the same way as a third or a fourth was allowed, might blush to take a second, lest they should be compared to those who were three or four times married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:13
verses.text: If more than one husband be allowed, it makes no difference whether he be a second or a third, because there is no longer a question of single marriage".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:14
verses.text: All things are lawful, but not all things are expedient".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:15
verses.text: I do not condemn second, nor third, nor, pardon the expression, eighth marriages: I will go still further and say that I welcome even a penitent whoremonger.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 15:16
verses.text: Things that are equally lawful must be weighed in an even balance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:2
verses.text: But he takes us to the Old Testament, and beginning with Adam goes on to Zacharias and Elizabeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:3
verses.text: He next confronts us with Peter and the rest of the Apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:4
verses.text: We are therefore bound to traverse the same course of argument and show that chastity was always preferred to the condition of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:5
verses.text: And as regards Adam and Eve we must maintain that before the fall they were virgins in Paradise: but after they sinned, and were cast out of Paradise, they were immediately married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:6
verses.text: Then we have the passage, "For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and the twain shall become one flesh," in explanation of which the Apostle straightway adds, "This mystery is great, but I speak in regard of Christ, and of the Church".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:7
verses.text: Christ in the flesh is a virgin, in the spirit he is once married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:8
verses.text: For he has one Church, concerning which the same Apostle says, "Husbands, love your wives, even as Christ also loved the Church".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:9
verses.text: If Christ loves the Church holily, chastely, and without spot, let husbands also love their wives in chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:10
verses.text: And let everyone know how to possess his vessel in sanctification and honour, not in the lust of concupiscence, as the Gentiles who know not God: "For God called us not for uncleanness, but in sanctification: seeing that ye have put off the old man with his doings, and have put on the new man, which is being renewed unto knowledge after the image of him that created him: where there cannot be male and female, Greek and Jew, circumcision and uncircumcision, barbarian, Scythian, bondman, freeman: but Christ is all, and in all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:11
verses.text: The link of marriage is not found in the image of the Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:12
verses.text: When difference of sex is done away, and we are putting off the old man, and putting on the new, then we are being born again into Christ a virgin, who was both born of a virgin, and is born again throughvirginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:13
verses.text: And whereas he says "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth," it was necessary first to plant the wood and to let it grow, so that there might be an after-growth for cutting down.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:14
verses.text: And at the same time we must bear in mind the meaning of the phrase, "replenish the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:15
verses.text: Marriage replenishes the earth, virginity fills Paradise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:16
verses.text: This too we must observe, at least if we would faithfully follow the Hebrew, that while Scripture on the first, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth days relates that, having finished the works of each, "God saw that it was good," on the second day it omitted this altogether, leaving us to understand that two is not a good number because it destroys unity, and prefigures the marriage compact.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:17
verses.text: Hence it was that all the animals which Noah took into the ark by pairs were unclean.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:18
verses.text: Odd numbers denote cleanness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:19
verses.text: And yet by the double number is represented another mystery: that not even in beasts and unclean birds is second marriage approved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 16:20
verses.text: For unclean animals went in two and two, and clean ones by sevens, so that Noah after the flood might be able to immediately offer to God sacrifices from the latter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 17:2
verses.text: But if Enoch was translated, and Noah was preserved at the deluge, I do not think that Enoch was translated because he had a wife, but because he was the first to call upon God and to believe in the Creator; and the Apostle Paul fully instructs us concerning him in the Epistle to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 17:3
verses.text: Noah, moreover, who was preserved as a kind of second root for the human race, must of course be preserved together with his wife and sons, although in this there is a Scripture mystery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 17:4
verses.text: The ark, according to the Apostle Peter, was a type of the Church, in which eight souls were saved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 17:5
verses.text: When Noah entered into it, both he and his sons were separated from their wives; but when he landed from it, they united in pairs, and what had been separated in the ark, that is, in the Church, was joined together in the intercourse of the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 17:6
verses.text: And at the same time if the ark had many compartments and little chambers, and was made with second and third stories, and was filled with different beasts, and was furnished with dwellings, great or small, according to the kind of animal, I think all this diversity in the compartments was a figure of the manifold character of the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:2
verses.text: He raises the objection that when God gave his second blessing, permission was granted to eat flesh, which had not in the first benediction been allowed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:3
verses.text: He should know that just as divorce according to the Saviour's word was not permitted from the beginning, but on account of the hardness of our heart was a concession of Moses to the human race, so too the eating of flesh was unknown until the deluge.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:4
verses.text: But after the deluge, like the quails given in the desert to the murmuring people, the poison of flesh-meat was offered to our teeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:5
verses.text: The Apostle writing to the Ephesians teaches that God had purposed in the fulness of time to sum up and renew in Christ Jesus all things which are in heaven and in earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:6
verses.text: Whence also the Saviour himself in the Revelation of John says, "I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:7
verses.text: At the beginning of the human race we neither ate flesh, nor gave bills of divorce, nor suffered circumcision for a sign.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:8
verses.text: Thus we reached the deluge.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:9
verses.text: But after the deluge, together with the giving of the law which no one could fulfil, flesh was given for food, and divorce was allowed to hard-hearted men, and the knife of circumcision was applied, as though the hand of God had fashioned us with something superfluous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:10
verses.text: But once Christ has come in the end of time, and Omega passed into Alpha and turned the end into the beginning, we are no longer allowed divorce, nor are we circumcised, nor do we eat flesh, for the Apostle says, "It is good not to eat flesh, nor to drink wine".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 18:11
verses.text: For wine as well as flesh was consecrated after the deluge.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:2
verses.text: What shall I say of Abraham who had three wives, as Jovinianus says, and received circumcision as a sign of his faith? If we follow him in the number of his wives, let us also follow him in circumcision.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:3
verses.text: We must not partly follow, partly reject him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:4
verses.text: Isaac, moreover, the husband of one wife, Rebecca, prefigures the Church of Christ, and reproves the wantonness of second marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:5
verses.text: And if Jacob had two pairs of wives and concubines, and our opponent will not admit that blear-eyed Leah, ugly and prolific, was a type of the synagogue, but that Rachel, beautiful and long barren, indicated the mystery of the Church, let me remind him that when Jacob did this thing he was among the Assyrians, and in Mesopotamia in bondage to a hard master.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:6
verses.text: But when he wished to enter the holy land, he raised on Mount Galeed the heap of witness, in token that the lord of Mesopotamia had failed to find anything among his baggage, and there swore that he would never return to the place of his bondage; and when,after wrestling with the angel at the brook Jabbok, he began to limp, because the great muscle of his thigh was withered, he at once gained the name of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 19:7
verses.text: Then the wife whom he once loved, and for whom he had served, was slain by the son of sorrow near Bethlehem which was destined to be the birthplace of our Lord, the herald of virginity: and the intimacies of Mesopotamia died in the land of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:2
verses.text: But I wonder why he setJudah and Tamar before us for an example, unless perchance even harlots give him pleasure; orOnan who was slain because he grudged his brother seed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:3
verses.text: Does he imagine that we approve of any sexual intercourse except for the procreation of children? As regards Moses, it is clear that he would have been in peril at the inn, ifSephora which is by interpretation a bird, had not circumcised her son, and cut off the foreskin of marriage with the knife which prefigured the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:4
verses.text: This is that Moses who when he saw a great vision and heard an angel, or the Lord speaking in the bush, could not by any means approach to him without first loosing the latchet of his shoe, that is, putting off the bonds of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:5
verses.text: And we need not be surprised at this in the case of one who was a prophet, lawgiver, and the friend of God, seeing that all the people when about to draw nigh to Mount Sinai, and to hear the voice speaking to them, were commanded to sanctify themselves in three days, and keep themselves from their wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:6
verses.text: I am out of order in violating historical sequence, but I may point out that the same thing was said byAhimelech the priest to David when he fled to Nob: "If only the young men have kept themselves from women".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:7
verses.text: And David answered, "of a truth about these three days".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:8
verses.text: For the shew-bread, like the body of Christ, might not be eaten by those who rose from the marriage bed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:9
verses.text: And in passing we ought to consider the words "if only the young men have kept themselves from women".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:10
verses.text: The truth is that, in view of the purity of the body of Christ, all sexual intercourse is unclean.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:11
verses.text: In the law also it is enjoined that thehigh priest must not marry any but a virgin, nor must he take to wife a widow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:12
verses.text: If a virgin and a widow are on the same level, how is it that one is taken, the other rejected?And the widow of a priest is bidden abide in the house of her father, and not to contract a second marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:13
verses.text: If the sister of a priest dies in virginity, just as the priest is commanded to go to the funeral of his father and mother, so must he go to hers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:14
verses.text: But if she be married, she is despised as though she belonged not to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:15
verses.text: He who hasmarried a wife, and he who has planted a vineyard, an image of the propagation of children, is forbidden to go to the battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:16
verses.text: For he who is the slave of his wife cannot be the Lord's soldier.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:17
verses.text: And the laver in the tabernacle was cast from the mirrors of the women whofasted, signifying the bodies of pure virgins: And within,in the sanctuary, both cherubim, and mercy-seat, and the ark of the covenant, and the table of shew-bread, and the candle-stick, and the censer, were made of the purest gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 20:18
verses.text: For silver might not be brought into the holy of holies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:2
verses.text: I must not linger over Moses when my purpose is at full speed to lightly touch on each topic and to sketch the outline of a proper knowledge of my subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:3
verses.text: I will pass to Joshua the son of Nun, who was previously called Ause, or better, as in the Hebrew, Osee, that is, Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:4
verses.text: For he,according to the epistle of Jude, saved the people of Israel and led them forth out of Egypt, and brought them into the land of promise.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:5
verses.text: As soon as this Joshua reached the Jordan, the waters of marriage, which had ever flowed in the land, dried up and stood in one heap; and the whole people, barefooted and on dry ground, crossed over, and came to Gilgal, and there was a second time circumcised.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:6
verses.text: If we take this literally, it cannot possibly stand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:7
verses.text: For if we had two foreskins, or if another could grow after the first was cut off, there would be room for speaking of a second circumcision.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:8
verses.text: But the meaning is that Joshua circumcised the people who had crossed the desert, with the Gospel knife, and he circumcised them with a stone knife, that what in the case of Moses' son was prefigured in a few might under Joshua be fulfilled in all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:9
verses.text: Moreover, the very foreskins were heaped together and buried, and covered with earth, and the fact that the reproach of Egypt was taken away, and the name of the place, Gilgal, which is by interpretationrevelation, show that while the people wandered in the desert uncircumcised their eyes were blinded.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:10
verses.text: Let us see what follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:11
verses.text: After this Gospel circumcision and the consecration of twelve stones at the place of revelation, the Passover was immediately celebrated, a lamb was slain for them, and they ate the food of the Holy Land.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:12
verses.text: Joshua went forth, and was met by the Prince of the host, sword in hand, that is either to shew that he was ready to fight for the circumcised people, or to sever the tie of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:13
verses.text: And in the same way that Moses was commanded, so was he: "loose thy shoe, for the place whereon thou standest is holy ground".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:14
verses.text: For if the armed host of the Lord was represented by the trumpets of the priests, we may see in Jericho a type of the overthrow of the world by the preaching of the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:15
verses.text: And to pass over endless details (for it is not my purpose now to unfold all the mysteries of the Old Testament),five kings who previously reigned in the land of promise, and opposed the Gospel army, were overcome in battle with Joshua.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:16
verses.text: I think it is clearly to be understood that before the Lord led his people from Egypt and circumcised them, sight, smell, taste, hearing, and touch had the dominion, and that to these, as to five princes, everything was subject.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 21:17
verses.text: And when they took refuge in the cave of the body and in a place of darkness, Jesus entered the body itself and slew them, that the source of their power might be the instrument of their death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:2
verses.text: But it is now time for us to raise the standard of Joshua's chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:3
verses.text: It is written that Moses had a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:4
verses.text: Now Moses is interpreted both by our Lord and by the Apostle to mean the law: "They have Moses and the prophets".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:5
verses.text: And "Death reigned from Adam until Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the likeness of Adam's transgression".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:6
verses.text: And no one doubts that in both passages Moses signifies the law.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:7
verses.text: We read that Moses, that is the law, had a wife: shew me then in the same way that Joshua the son of Nun had either wife or children, and if you can do so, I will confess that I am beaten.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:8
verses.text: He certainly received the fairest spot in the division of the land of Judah, and died, not in the twenties, which are ever unlucky in Scripture—by them are reckoned the years ofJacob's service,the price of Joseph, andsundry presents which Esau who was fond of them received—but in thetens, whose praises we have often sung; and he was buried inThamnath Sare, that is, most perfect sovereignty, or among those of a new covering, to signify the crowds of virgins, covered by the Saviour's aid on Mount Ephraim, that is, the fruitful mountain; on the north of the Mountain of Gaash, which is, being interpreted, disturbance: for"Mount Sion is on the sides of the north, the city of the Great King," is ever exposed to hatred, and in every trial says "But my feet had well nigh slipped".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:9
verses.text: The book which bears the name of Joshua ends with his burial.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:10
verses.text: Again in the book of Judges we read of him as though he had risen and come to life again, and by way of summary his works are extolled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:11
verses.text: We read too "So Joshua sent the people away, every man unto his inheritance, that they might possess the land".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:12
verses.text: And "Israel served the Lord all the days of Joshua," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:13
verses.text: There immediately follows: "And Joshua the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died, being an hundred and ten years old".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:14
verses.text: Moses, moreover, only saw the land of promise; he could not enter: and "he died in the land of Moab, and the Lord buried him in the valley in the land of Moab over against Beth-peor: but no man knoweth of his sepulchre unto this day".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:15
verses.text: Let us compare the burial of the two: Moses died in the land of Moab, Joshua in the land of Judaea.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:16
verses.text: The former was buried in a valley over against the house of Phogor, which is, being interpreted, reproach (for the Hebrew Phogor corresponds to Priapus); the latter in Mount Ephraim on the north of Mount Gaash.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:17
verses.text: And in the simple expressions of the sacred Scriptures there is always a more subtle meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:18
verses.text: The Jews gloried in children and child-bearing; and the barren woman, who had not offspring in Israel, was accursed; but blessed was he whose seed was in Sion, and his family in Jerusalem; and part of the highest blessing was, "Thy wife shall be as a fruitful vine, in the innermost parts of thy house, thy children like olive plants, round about thy table".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:19
verses.text: Therefore his grave is described as placed in a valley over against the house of an idol which was in a special sense consecrated to lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:20
verses.text: But we who fight under Joshua our leader, even to the present day know not where Moses was buried.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:21
verses.text: For we despise Phogor, and all his shame, knowing that they who are in the flesh cannot please God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:22
verses.text: And the Lord before the flood had said"My spirit shall not abide in man for ever, for that he also is flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:23
verses.text: Wherefore, when Moses died, the people of Israel mourned for him; but Joshua like one on his way to victory was unmourned.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 22:24
verses.text: For marriage ends at death; virginity thereafter begins to wear the crown.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:2
verses.text: Next he brings forward Samson, and does not consider that the Lord's Nazarite was once shaven bald by a woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:3
verses.text: And although Samson continues to be a type of the Saviour because he loved a harlot from among the Gentiles, which harlot corresponds to the Church, and because he slew more enemies in his death than he did in his life, yet he does not set an example of conjugal chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:4
verses.text: And he surely reminds us of Jacob's prophecy—he was shaken by his runaway steed, bitten by an adder and fell backwards.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:5
verses.text: But why he enumerated Deborah, and Barak, and the wife of Heber the Kenite, I am at a loss to understand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:6
verses.text: For it is one thing to draw up a list of military commanders in historical sequence, another to indicate certain figures of marriage which cannot be found in them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:7
verses.text: And whereas he prefers the fidelity of the father Jephthah to the tears of the virgin daughter, that makes for us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:8
verses.text: For we are not commending virgins of the world so much as those who are virgins for Christ's sake, and most Hebrews blame the father for the rash vow he made, "If thou wilt indeed deliver the children of Ammon into mine hand, then it shall be, that whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the children of Ammon, it shall be for the Lord's, and I will offer it up for a burnt offering".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:9
verses.text: Supposing (they say) a dog or an ass had met him, what would he have done? Their meaning is that God so ordered events that he who had improvidently made a vow, should learn his error by the death of his daughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:10
verses.text: And if Samuel who was brought up in the tabernacle married a wife, how does that prejudice virginity? As if at the present day also there were not many married priests, and as though the Apostle did not describe a bishop as the husband of one wife, having children with all purity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:11
verses.text: At the same time we must not forget that Samuel was a Levite, not a priest or high-priest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:12
verses.text: Hence it was that his mother made for him a linen ephod, that is, a linen garment to go over the shoulders, which was the proper dress of the Levites and of the inferior order.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:13
verses.text: And so he is not named in the Psalms among the priests, but among those who call upon the name of the Lord: "Moses and Aaron among his priests, and Samuel among those who call upon his name".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:14
verses.text: ForLevi begat Kohath, Kohath begat Amminadab, Amminadab begat Korah, Korah begat Assir, Assir begat Elkanah, Elkanah begat Zuph, Zuph begat Tahath, Tahath begat Eliel, Eliel begat Jeroham, Jeroham begat Elkanah, Elkanah begat Samuel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:15
verses.text: And no one doubts that the priests sprang from the stock of Aaron, Eleazar, and Phinees.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:16
verses.text: And seeing that they had wives, they would be rightly brought against us, if, led away by the error of the Encratites, we were to maintain that marriage deserved censure, and our high priest were not after the order of Melchizedek, without father, without mother, Α᾽γενεαλόγητος , that is, unmarried.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:17
verses.text: And much fruit truly did Samuel reap from his children! he himself pleased God, but begat such children as displeased the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:18
verses.text: But if in support of second marriage, he urges the instance of Boaz and Ruth, let him know that in the Gospel (S.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:19
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:20
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 23:21
verses.text: 6) to typify the Church even Rahab the harlot is reckoned among our Lord's ancestors.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:2
verses.text: He boasts that David bought his wife for two hundred foreskins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:3
verses.text: But he should remember that David had numerous other wives, and afterwards received Michal, Saul's daughter, whom her father had delivered to another, and when he was old got heat from the embrace of the Shunammite maiden.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:4
verses.text: And I do not say this because I am bold enough to disparage holy men, but because it is one thing to live under the law, another to live under the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:5
verses.text: David slew Uriah the Hittite and committed adultery with Bathsheba.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:6
verses.text: And because he was a man of blood—the reference is not, as some think, to his wars, but to the murder—he was not permitted to build a temple of the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:7
verses.text: But as for us, if we cause one of the least to stumble, and if we say to a brother Raca, oruse our eyes improperly, it were good that a millstone were hanged about our neck, we shall be in danger of Gehenna, and a mere glance will be reckoned to us for adultery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:8
verses.text: He passes on to Solomon, through whom wisdom itself sang its own praises.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:9
verses.text: Seeing that not content with dwelling upon his praises, he calls him uxorious, I am surprised that he did not add the words of the Canticles: "There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, and maidens without number," and those of the First Book of Kings; And he had seven hundred wives, princesses, and three hundred concubines, and others without number".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:10
verses.text: These are they who turned away his heart from the Lord: and yet before he had many wives, and fell into sins of the flesh, at the beginning of his reign and in his early years he built a temple to the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:11
verses.text: For every one is judged not for what he will be, but for what he is.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:12
verses.text: But if Jovinianus approves the example of Solomon, he will no longer be in favour of second and third marriages only, but unless he has seven hundred wives and three hundred concubines, he cannot be the king's antitype or attain to his merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:13
verses.text: I earnestly again and again remind you, my reader, that I am compelled to speak as I do, and that I do not disparage our predecessors under the law, but am well aware that they served their generation according to their circumstances, and fulfilled the Lord's command to increase, and multiply, and replenish the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:14
verses.text: And what is more they were figures of those that were to come.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 24:15
verses.text: But we to whom it is said, "The time is shortened, that henceforth those that have wives may be as though they had none," have a different command, and for us virginity is consecrated by the Virgin Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:2
verses.text: What folly it was to include Elijah and Elisha in a list of married men, is plain without a word from me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:3
verses.text: For, since John Baptist came in the spirit and power of Elijah, and John was a virgin, it is clear that he came not only in Elijah's spirit, but also in his bodily chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:4
verses.text: Then the passage relating to Hezekiah might be adduced (though Jovinianus with his wonted stupidity did not notice it), in which after his recovery and the addition of fifteen years to his life he said, "Now will I beget children".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:5
verses.text: It must be remembered, however, that in the Hebrew texts the passage is not so, but runs thus: "The father to the children shall make known thy faithfulness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:6
verses.text: Nor need we wonder that Huldah, the prophetess, and wife of Shallum, was consulted by Josiah, King of Judah, when the captivity was approaching and the wrath of the Lord was falling upon Jerusalem: since it is the rule of Scripture when holy men fail, to praise women to the reproach of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:7
verses.text: And it is superfluous to speak of Daniel, for the Hebrews to the present day affirm that the three youths were eunuchs, in accordance with the declaration of God which Isaiah utters to Hezekiah: "And of thy sons that shall issue from thee, which thou shalt beget, shall they take away: and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the King of Babylon".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:8
verses.text: And again in Daniel we read: "And the king spake unto Ashpenaz the master of his eunuchs, that he should bring in certain of the children of Israel, even of the seed royal and of the nobles: youth in whom was no blemish, but well favoured, and skilful in all wisdom, and cunning in knowledge, and understanding science".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:9
verses.text: The conclusion is that if Daniel and the three youths were chosen from the seed royal, and if Scripture foretold that that there should be eunuchs of the seed royal, these men were those who were made eunuchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:10
verses.text: If he meets us with the argument that in Ezekiel it is said that Noah, Daniel and Job in a sinful land could not free their sons and daughters, we reply that the words are used hypothetically.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:11
verses.text: Noah and Job were not in existence at that time: we know that they lived many ages before.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:12
verses.text: And the meaning is this: if there were such and such men in a sinful land, they shall not be able to save their own sons and daughters: because the righteousness of the father shall not save the son, nor shall the sin of one be imputed to another".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:13
verses.text: For the soul that sinneth, it shall die".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:14
verses.text: This, too, must be said, that Daniel, as the history of his book shows, was taken captive with King Jehoiakim at the same time that Ezekiel was also led into captivity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:15
verses.text: How then could he have sons who was still a youth? And only three years had elapsed when he was brought in to wait upon the king.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:16
verses.text: Let no one suppose that Ezekiel at this time remembers Daniel as a man, not as a youth; for "It came to pass," he says, "in the sixth year," that is of King Jehoiakim, "in the sixth month, in the fifth day of the month:" and, "as I sat in my house, and the elders of Judah sat before me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:17
verses.text: Yet on that same day it was said to him, "Though these three men, Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:18
verses.text: Daniel was therefore a youth, and known to the people, either on account of his interpretation of the king's dreams, or on account of the release of Susannah, and the slaying of the elders.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:19
verses.text: And it is clearly proved that at the time these things were spoken of Noah, Daniel, and Job, Daniel was still a youth and could not have had sons and daughters, whom he might save by his righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 25:20
verses.text: So far concerning the Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:2
verses.text: Coming to the Gospel he sets before us Zacharias and Elizabeth, Peter and his mother-in-law, and, with a shamelessness to which we have now grown accustomed, fails to understand that they, too, ought to have been reckoned among those who served the Law.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:3
verses.text: For the Gospel had no being before the crucifixion of Christ—it was consecrated by His passion and by His blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:4
verses.text: In accordance with this rule Peter and the other Apostles (I must give Jovinianus something now and then out of my abundance) had indeed wives, but those which they had taken before they knew the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:5
verses.text: But once they were received into the Apostolate, they forsook the offices of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:6
verses.text: For when Peter, representing the Apostles, says to the Lord: "Lo we have left all and followed thee," the Lord answered him, "Verily I say unto you, there is no man that hath left house or wife, or brethren, or parents, or children for the kingdom of God's sake, who shall not receive manifold more in this time, and in the world to come eternal life".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:7
verses.text: But if, in order to show that all the Apostles had wives, he meets us with the words "Have we no right to lead about women or wives" (for γυνή in Greek has both meanings) "even as the rest of the apostles, and Cephas, and the brethren of the Lord?" let him add what is found in the Greek copies, "Have we no right to lead about women that are sisters, or wives?" This makes it clear that the writer referred to other holy women, who, in accordance with Jewish custom, ministered to their teachers of their substance, as we read was the practice with even our Lord himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:8
verses.text: Where there is a previous reference to eating and drinking, and the outlay of money, and mention is afterwards made of women that are sisters, it is quite clear, as we have said, that we must understand, not wives, but those women who ministered of their substance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:9
verses.text: And we read the same account in the Old Testament of the Shunammite who was wont to welcome Elisha, and to put for him a table, and bread, and a candlestick, and the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:10
verses.text: At all events if we take γυναίκας to mean wives, not women, the addition of the word sisters destroys the effect of the word wives, and shews that they were related in spirit, not by wedlock.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:11
verses.text: Nevertheless, with the exception of the Apostle Peter, it is not openly stated that the Apostles had wives; and since the statement is made of one while nothing is said about the rest, we must understand that those of whom Scripture gives no such description had no wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:12
verses.text: Yet Jovinianus, who has arrayed against us Zacharias and Elizabeth, Peter and his wife's mother, should know, that John was the son of Zacharias and Elizabeth, that is, a virgin was the offspring of marriage, the Gospel of the law, chastity of matrimony; so that by a virgin prophet the virgin Lord might be both announced and baptized.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:13
verses.text: But we might say concerning Peter, that he had a mother-in-law when he believed, and no longer had a wife, although in the "Sentences" we read of both his wife and daughter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:14
verses.text: But for the present our argument must be based wholly on Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:15
verses.text: He has made his appeal to the Apostles, because he thinks that they, who hold the chief authority in our moral system and are the typical Christian teachers, were not virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:16
verses.text: If, then, we allow that they were not virgins (and, with the exception of Peter, the point cannot be proved), yet I must tell him that it is to the Apostles that the words of Isaiah relate: "Except the Lord of hosts had left unto us a small remnant, we should have been as Sodom, we should have been like unto Gomorrah".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:17
verses.text: So, then, they who were by birth Jews could not under the Gospel recover the virginity which they had lost in Judaism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:18
verses.text: And yet John, one of the disciples, who is related to have been the youngest of the Apostles, and who was a virgin when he embraced Christianity, remained a virgin, and on that account was more beloved by our Lord, and lay upon the breast of Jesus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:19
verses.text: And what Peter, who had had a wife, did not dare ask, he requested John to ask.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:20
verses.text: And after the resurrection, when Mary Magdalene told them that the Lord had risen, they both ran to the sepulchre, but John outran Peter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:21
verses.text: And when they were fishing in the ship on the lake of Gennesaret, Jesus stood upon the shore, and the Apostles knew not who it was they saw; the virgin alone recognized a virgin, and said to Peter, "It is the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:22
verses.text: Again, after hearing the prediction that he must be bound by another, and led whither he would not, and must suffer on the cross, Peter said, "Lord what shall this man do?" being unwilling to desert John, with whom he had always been united.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:23
verses.text: Our Lord said to him, "What is that to thee if I wish him so to be?" Whence the saying went abroad among the brethren that that disciple should not die.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:24
verses.text: Here we have a proof that virginity does not die, and that the defilement of marriage is not washed away by the blood of martyrdom, but virginity abides with Christ, and its sleep is not death but a passing to another state.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:25
verses.text: If, however, Jovinianus should obstinately contend that John was not a virgin, (whereas we have maintained that his virginity was the cause of the special love our Lord bore to him), let him explain, if he was not a virgin, why it was that he was loved more than the other Apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:26
verses.text: But you say,the Church was founded upon Peter: althoughelsewhere the same is attributed to all the Apostles, and they all receive the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and the strength of the Church depends upon them all alike, yet one among the twelve is chosen so that when a head has been appointed, there may be no occasion for schism.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:27
verses.text: But why was not John chosen, who was a virgin? Deference was paid to age, because Peter was the elder: one who was a youth, I may say almost a boy, could not be set over men of advanced age; and a good master who was bound to remove every occasion of strife among his disciples, and who had said to them, "Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you," and,"He that is the greater among you, let him be the least of all," would not be thought to afford cause of envy against the youth whom he had loved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:28
verses.text: We maybe sure that John was then a boy because ecclesiastical history most clearly proves that he lived to the reign of Trajan, that is, he fell asleep in the sixty-eighth year after our Lord's passion, as I have briefly noted in my treatise on Illustrious Men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:29
verses.text: Peter is an Apostle, and John is an Apostle—the one a married man, the other a virgin; but Peter is an Apostle only, John is both an Apostle and an Evangelist, and a prophet.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:30
verses.text: An Apostle, because he wrote to the Churches as a master; an Evangelist, because he composed a Gospel, a thing which no other of the Apostles, excepting Matthew, did; a prophet, for he saw in the island of Patmos, to which he had been banished by the Emperor Domitian as a martyr for the Lord, an Apocalypse containing the boundless mysteries of the future.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:31
verses.text: Tertullian, more over, relates that he was sent to Rome, and that having been plunged into a jar of boiling oil he came out fresher and more active than when he went in.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:32
verses.text: But his very Gospel is widely different from the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:33
verses.text: Matthew as though he were writing of a man begins thus: "The book of the Generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham;" Luke begins with the priesthood of Zacharias; Mark with a prophecy of the prophets Malachi and Isaiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:34
verses.text: The first has the face of a man, on account of the genealogical table; the second, the face of a calf, on account of the priesthood; the third, the face of a lion, on account of the voice of one crying in the desert,"Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:35
verses.text: But John like an eagle soars aloft, and reaches the Father Himself, and says, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:36
verses.text: The same was in the beginning with God," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 26:37
verses.text: The virgin writer expounded mysteries which the married could not, and to briefly sum up all and show how great was the privilege of John, or rather of virginity in John, the Virgin Mother was entrusted by the Virgin Lord to the Virgin disciple.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:2
verses.text: But we toil to no purpose.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:3
verses.text: For our opponent urges against us the Apostolic sentence and says, "Adam was first formed, then Eve; and Adam was not beguiled, but the woman being beguiled hath fallen into transgression: but she shall be saved through the child-bearing, if they continue in faith and love and sanctification with sobriety".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:4
verses.text: Let us consider what led the Apostle to make this declaration:"I desire therefore that the men pray in every place, lifting up holy hands, without wrath and disputing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:5
verses.text: So in due course he lays down rules of life for the women and says "In like manner that women adorn themselves in modest apparel, with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with braided hair, and gold or pearls or costly raiment; but (which becometh women professing godliness) through good works.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:6
verses.text: Let a woman learn in quietness with all subjection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:7
verses.text: But I permit not a woman to teach, nor to have dominion over a man, but to be in quietness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:8
verses.text: And that the lot of a woman might not seem a hard one, reducing her to the condition of a slave to her husband, the Apostle recalls the ancient law and goes back to the first example: that Adam was first made, then the woman out of his rib; and that the Devil could not seduce Adam, but did seduce Eve; and that after displeasing God she was immediately subjected to the man, and began to turn to her husband; and he points out that she who was once tied with the bonds of marriage and was reduced to the condition of Eve, might blot out the old transgression by the procreation of children: provided, however, that she bring up the children themselves in the faith and love of Christ, and in sanctification and chastity; for we must not adopt the faulty reading of the Latin texts, sobrietas, but castitas, that is,σωφροσύνη.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:9
verses.text: You see how you are mastered by the witness of this passage also, and cannot but be driven to admit that what you thought was on the side of marriage tells in favour of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 27:10
verses.text: For if the woman is saved in child-bearing, and the more the children the greater the safety of the mothers, why did he add "if they continue in faith and love and sanctification with chastity"? The woman will then be saved, if she bear not children who will remain virgins: if what she has herself lost, she attains in her children, and makes up for the loss and decay, of the root by the excellence of the flower and fruit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:2
verses.text: Above, in passing, when our opponent adduced Solomon, who, although he had many wives, nevertheless built the temple, I briefly replied that it was my intention to run over the remaining points.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:3
verses.text: Now that he may not cry out that both Solomon and others under the law, prophets and holy men, have been dishonoured by us, let us show what this very man with his many wives and concubines thought of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:4
verses.text: For no one can know better than he who suffered through them, what a wife or woman is.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:5
verses.text: Well then, he says in the Proverbs:"The foolish and bold woman comes to want bread".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:6
verses.text: What bread? Surely that bread which cometh down from heaven: and he immediately adds "The earth-born perish in her house, rush into the depths of hell".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:7
verses.text: Who are the earth-born that perish in her house? They of course who follow the first Adam, who is of the earth, and not the second, who is from heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:8
verses.text: And again in another place: "Like a worm in wood, so a wicked woman destroyeth her husband".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:9
verses.text: But if you assert that this was spoken of bad wives, I shall briefly answer: What necessity rests upon me to run the risk of the wife I marry proving good or bad?"It is better," he says, "to dwell in a desert land, than with a contentious and passionate woman in a wide house".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:10
verses.text: How seldom we find a wife without these faults, he knows who is married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:11
verses.text: Hence that sublime orator, Varius Geminus says well "The man who does not quarrel is a bachelor".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:12
verses.text: "It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a contentious woman in a house in common".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:13
verses.text: If a house common to husband and wife makes a wife proud and breeds contempt for the husband: how much more if the wife be the richer of the two, and the husband but a lodger in her house! She begins to be not a wife, but mistress of the house; and if she offend her husband, they must part".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:14
verses.text: A continual dropping on a wintry day" turns a man out of doors, and so will a contentious woman drive a man from his own house.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:15
verses.text: She floods his house with her constant nagging and daily chatter, and ousts him from his own home, that is the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:16
verses.text: Hence the same Solomon previously commands:"My son flows forth beyond".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:17
verses.text: And the Apostle, writing to the Hebrews, says "Therefore we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things spoken, lest haply we flow forth beyond".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:18
verses.text: But who can hide from himself what is thus enigmatically expressed?"The horseleech had three daughters, dearly loved, but they satisfied her not, and a fourth is not satisfied when you say Enough; the grave, and woman's love, and the earth that is not satisfied with water, and the fire that saith not, Enough".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:19
verses.text: The horse-leech is the devil, the daughters of the devil are dearly loved, and they cannot be satisfied with the blood of the slain: the grave, and woman's love, and the earth dry and scorched with heat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:20
verses.text: It is not the harlot, or the adulteress who is spoken of; but woman's love in general is accused of ever being insatiable; put it out, it bursts into flame; give it plenty, it is again in need; it enervates a man's mind, and engrosses all thought except for the passion which it feeds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:21
verses.text: What we read in the parable which follows is to the same effect: "For three things the earth doth tremble, and for four which it cannot bear: for a servant when he is king: and a fool when he is filled with meat: for an odious woman when she is married to a good husband: and an handmaid that is heir to her mistress".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:22
verses.text: See how a wife is classed with the greatest evils.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:23
verses.text: But if you reply that it is an odious wife, I will give you the same answer as before—the mere possibility of such danger is in itself no light matter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:24
verses.text: For he who marries a wife is uncertain whether he is marrying an odious woman or one worthy of his love.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:25
verses.text: If she be odious, she is intolerable.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 28:26
verses.text: If worthy of love, her love is compared to the grave, to the parched earth, and to fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:2
verses.text: Let us come to Ecclesiastes and adduce a few corroborative passages from him also".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:3
verses.text: To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven: a time to be born, and a time to die: a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:4
verses.text: We brought forth young under the law with Moses, let us die under the Gospel with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:5
verses.text: We planted in marriage, let us by chastity pluck up that which was planted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:6
verses.text: "A time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing: a time to love, and a time to hate: a time for war, and a time for peace".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:7
verses.text: And at the same time he warns us not to prefer the law to the Gospel; nor to think that virgin purity is to be placed on a level with marriage:"Better," he says, "is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:8
verses.text: And he immediately adds: "Say not thou, what is the cause that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not inquire wisely concerning this".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:9
verses.text: And he gives the reason why the latter days are better than the former:"For wisdom with an inheritance is good".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:10
verses.text: Under the law carnal wisdom was followed by the sword of death; under the Gospel an eternal inheritance awaits spiritual wisdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:11
verses.text: "Behold, this have I found,saith the Preacher, one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all those have I not found.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:12
verses.text: Behold this only have I found, that God made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:13
verses.text: He says that he had found man upright.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:14
verses.text: Consider the force of the words.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:15
verses.text: The word man comprehends both male and female.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:16
verses.text: "But a woman," he says, "among all these have I not found".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:17
verses.text: Let us read the beginning of Genesis, and we shall find Adam, that is man, called both male and female.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:18
verses.text: Having then been created by God good and upright, by our own fault we have fallen to a worse condition; and that which in Paradise had been upright, when we left Paradise was corrupt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:19
verses.text: If you object that before they sinned there was a distinction in sex between male and female, and that they could without sin have come together, it is uncertain what might have happened.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:20
verses.text: For we cannot know the judgements of God, and anticipate his sentence as we choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:21
verses.text: What really happened is plain enough,—that they who in Paradise remained in perpetual virginity, when they were expelled from Paradise were joined together.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:22
verses.text: Or if Paradise admits of marriage, and there is no difference between marriage and virginity, what prevented their previous intercourse even in Paradise? They are driven out of Paradise; and what they did not there, they do on earth; so that from the very earliest days of humanity virginity was consecrated by Paradise, and marriage by earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:23
verses.text: Let thy garments be always white".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:24
verses.text: The eternal whiteness of our garments is the purity of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:25
verses.text: In the morning we sowed our seed, and in the evening let us not cease.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 29:26
verses.text: Let us who served marriage under the law, serve virginity under the Gospel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:2
verses.text: I pass to the Song of Songs, and whereas our opponent thinks it makes altogether for marriage, I shall show that it contains the mysteries of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:3
verses.text: Let us hear what the bride says before that the bridegroom comes to earth, suffers, descends to the lower world, and rises again".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:4
verses.text: We will make for thee likenesses of gold with ornaments of silver while the king sits at his table".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:5
verses.text: Before the Lord rose again, and the Gospel shone, the bride had not gold, but likenesses of gold.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:6
verses.text: As for the silver, however, which she professes to have at the marriage, she not only had silver ornaments, but she had them in variety—in widows, in the continent, and in the married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:7
verses.text: Then the bridegroom makes answer to the bride, and teaches her that the shadow of the old law has passed away, and the truth of the Gospel has come".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:8
verses.text: Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away, for lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:9
verses.text: This relates to the Old Testament.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:10
verses.text: Once more he speaks of the Gospel and of virginity: "The flowers appear on the earth, the time of the pruning of vines has come".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:11
verses.text: Does he not seem to you to say the very same thing that the Apostle says: "The time is shortened that henceforth both those that have wives may be as though they had none"? And more plainly does he herald chastity: "The voice," he says, "of the turtle is heard in our land".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:12
verses.text: The turtle, the chastest of birds, always dwelling in lofty places, is a type of the Saviour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:13
verses.text: Let us read the works of naturalists and we shall find that it is the nature of the turtle-dove, if it lose its mate, not to take another; and we shall understand that second marriage is repudiated even by dumb birds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:14
verses.text: And immediately the turtle says to its fellow: "The fig tree hath put forth its green figs," that is, the commandments of the old law have fallen, and the blossoming vines of the Gospel give forth their fragrance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:15
verses.text: Whence the Apostle also says, "We are a sweet savour of Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:16
verses.text: "Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:17
verses.text: O my dove, thou art in the clefts of the rock, in the covert of the steep place.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:18
verses.text: Let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:19
verses.text: Whilst thou coveredst thy countenance like Moses and the veil of the law remained, I neither saw thy face, nor did I condescend to hear thy voice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:20
verses.text: I said,"Yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:21
verses.text: But now with unveiled face behold my glory, and shelter thyself in the cleft and steep places of the solid rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:22
verses.text: On hearing this the bride disclosed the mysteries of chastity:"My beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth his flock among the lilies," that is among the pure virgin bands.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:23
verses.text: Would you know what sort of a throne our true Solomon, the Prince of Peace, has, and what his attendants are like?"Behold," he says, "it is the litter of Solomon: threescore mighty men are about it, of the mighty men of Israel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:24
verses.text: They all handle the sword, and are expert in war: every man hath his sword upon his thigh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:25
verses.text: They who are about Solomon have their sword upon their thigh, like Ehud, the left-handed judge, who slew the fattest of foes, a man devoted to the flesh, and cut short all his pleasures".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:26
verses.text: I will get me," he says, "to the mountain of myrrh;" to those, that is, who have mortified their bodies; "and to the hill of frankincense," to the crowds of pure virgins; "and I will say to my bride, thou art all fair, my love, and there is no spot in thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:27
verses.text: Whence too the Apostle:"That he might present the church to himself a glorious church, not having spot or wrinkle, or any such thing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:28
verses.text: "Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, with me from Lebanon.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:29
verses.text: Thou shalt come and pass on from the beginning of faith, from the top of Sanir and Hermon, from the lions' dens, from the mountains of the leopards".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:30
verses.text: Lebanon is, being interpreted, whiteness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:31
verses.text: Come then, fairest bride, concerning whom it is elsewhere said "Who is she that cometh up, all in white?" and pass on by way of this world, from the beginning of faith, and from Sanir, which is by interpretation, God of light, as we read in the psalm: "Thy word is a lantern unto my feet, and light unto my path;" and "from Hermon," that is, consecration: and "flee from the lions' dens, and the mountains of the leopards who cannot change their spots".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:32
verses.text: Flee, he says, from the lions' dens, flee from the pride of devils, that when thou hast been consecrated to me, I may be able to say unto thee: "Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my bride, thou hast ravished mine heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:33
verses.text: What he says is something like this—I do not reject marriage: you have a second eye, the left, which I have given to you on account of the weakness of those who cannot see the right.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:34
verses.text: But I am pleased with the right eye of virginity, and if it be blinded the whole body is in darkness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:35
