verses.text: And that we might not think he had in view carnal love and bodily marriage, he at once excludes this meaning by saying"Thou hast ravished my heart, my bride, my sister".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:36
verses.text: The name sister excludes all suspicion of unhallowed love.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:37
verses.text: "How fair are thy breasts with wine," those breasts concerning which he had said above, My beloved is mine, and I am his: "betwixt my breasts shall he lie," that is in the princely portion of the heart where the Word of God has its lodging.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:38
verses.text: What wine is that which gives beauty to the breasts of the bride, and fills them with the milk of chastity? That, forsooth, of which the bridegroom goes on to speak: "I have drunk my wine with my milk.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:39
verses.text: Eat, O friends: yea, drink and be drunken, my brethren".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:40
verses.text: Hence the Apostles also were said to be filled with new wine; with new, he says, not with old wine; because new wine is put into fresh wine-skins, and they did not walk in oldness of the letter, but in newness of the Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:41
verses.text: This is wine wherewith when youths and maidens are intoxicated, they at once thirst for virginity; they are filled with the spirit of chastity, and the prophecy of Zechariah comes to pass, at least if we follow the Hebrew literally, for he prophesied concerning virgins: "And the streets of the city shall be full of boys and girls playing in the streets thereof.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:42
verses.text: For what is his goodness, and what is his beauty, but the corn of the elect, and wine that giveth birth to virgins?" They are virgins of whom it is written in the forty-fifth psalm: "The virgins her companions that follow her shall be brought unto thee.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 30:43
verses.text: With gladness and rejoicing shall they be led: they shall enter into the King's palace".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:2
verses.text: Then follows: "A garden shut up is my sister, my bride: a garden shut up, a fountain sealed".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:3
verses.text: That which is shut up and sealed reminds us of the mother of our Lord who was a mother and a Virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:4
verses.text: Hence it was that no one before or after our Saviour was laid in his new tomb, hewn in the solid rock.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:5
verses.text: And yet she that was ever a Virgin is the mother of many virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:6
verses.text: For next we read: "Thy shoots are an orchard of pomegranates with precious fruits".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:7
verses.text: By pomegranates and fruits is signified the blending of all virtues in virginity".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:8
verses.text: My beloved is white and ruddy"; white in virginity, ruddy in martyrdom.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:9
verses.text: And because He is white and ruddy, therefore it is immediately added"His mouth is most sweet, yea, he is altogether lovely".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:10
verses.text: The virgin bridegroom having been praised by the virgin bride, in turn praises the virgin bride, and says to her:"How beautiful are thy feet in sandals,O daughter of Aminadab," which is, being interpreted, a people that offereth itself willingly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:11
verses.text: For virginity is voluntary, and therefore the steps of the Church in the beauty of chastity are praised.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 31:12
verses.text: This is not the time for me like a commentator to explain all the mysteries of virginity from the Song of Songs; I have no doubt that the fastidious reader will turn up his nose at what has already been said.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:2
verses.text: Isaiah tells of the mystery of our faith and hope:"Behold a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Emmanuel".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:3
verses.text: I know that the Jews are accustomed to meet us with the objection that in Hebrew the word Almah does not mean a virgin, but a young woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:4
verses.text: And, to speak truth, a virgin is properly called Bethulah, but a young woman, or a girl, is not Almah, but Naarah!What then is the meaning of Almah? A hidden virgin, that is, not merely virgin, but a virgin and something more, because not every virgin is hidden, shut off from the occasional sight of men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:5
verses.text: Then again, Rebecca, on account of her extreme purity, and because she was a type of the Church which she represented in her own virginity, is described in Genesis as Almah, not Bethulah, as may clearly be proved from the words of Abraham's servant, spoken by him in Mesopotamia:"And he said, O Lord, the God of my master Abraham, if now thou do prosper my way which I go: behold I stand by the fountain of water; and let it come to pass, that the maiden which cometh forth to draw, to whom I shall say, Give me, I pray thee, a little water of this pitcher to drink; and she shall say to me, Both drink thou, and I will also draw for thy camels: let the same be the woman whom the Lord hath appointed for my master's son".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:6
verses.text: Where he speaks of the maiden coming forth to draw water, the Hebrew word is Almah, that is, a virgin secluded, and guarded by her parents with extreme care.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:7
verses.text: Or, if this be not so, let them at least show me where the word is applied to married women as well, and I will confess my ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:8
verses.text: "Behold a virgin shall conceive and bear a son".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:9
verses.text: If virginity be not preferred to marriage, why did not the Holy Spirit choose a married woman, or a widow? For at that time Anna the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aser, was alive, distinguished for purity, and always free to devote herself to prayers and fasting in the temple of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:10
verses.text: If the life, and good works, and fasting without virginity can merit the advent of the Holy Spirit, she might well have been the mother of our Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:11
verses.text: Let us hasten to the rest:"The virgin daughter of Zion hath despised thee and laughed thee to scorn".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:12
verses.text: To her whom he called daughter the prophet also gave the title virgin, for fear that if he spoke only of a daughter, it might be supposed that she was married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:13
verses.text: This is the virgin daughter whom elsewhere he thus addresses:"Sing, O barren, thou that dost not bear; break forth into singing, and cry aloud, thou that didst not travail with child: for more are the children of the desolate, than the children of the married wife, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:14
verses.text: This is she of whom God by the mouth of Jeremiah speaks, saying:"Can a maid forget her ornaments, or a bride her attire".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 32:15
verses.text: Concerning her we read of a great miracle in the same prophecy—that a woman should compass a man, and that the Father of all things should be contained in a virgin's womb.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:2
verses.text: "Granted," says Jovinianus, "that there is a difference between marriage and virginity, what have you to say to this,—Suppose a virgin and a widow were baptized, and continued as they were, what difference will there be between them?" What we have already said concerning Peter and John, Anna and Mary, may be of service here.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:3
verses.text: For if there is no difference between a virgin and a widow, both being baptized, because baptism makes a new man, upon the same principle harlots and prostitutes, if they are baptized, will be equal to virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:4
verses.text: If previous marriage is no prejudice to a baptized widow, and past pleasures and the exposure of their bodies to public lust are no detriment in the case of harlots, once they have approached the laver they will gain the rewards of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:5
verses.text: It is one thing to unite with God a mind pure and free from any stain of memory, another to remember the foul and forced embraces of a man, and in recollection to act a part which you do not in person.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:6
verses.text: Jeremiah, who wassanctified in the womb, and was known in his mother's belly, enjoyed the high privilege because he was predestined to the blessing of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:7
verses.text: And when all were captured, and even the vessels of the temple were plundered by the King of Babylon, he alone wasliberated by the enemy, knew not the insults of captivity, and was supported by the conquerors; and Nebuchadnezzar, though he gave Nebuzaradan no charge concerning the Holy of Holies, did give him charge concerning Jeremiah.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:8
verses.text: For that is the true temple of God, and that is the Holy of Holies, which is consecrated to the Lord by pure virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:9
verses.text: On the other hand, Ezekiel, who was kept captive in Babylon, who saw the storm approaching from the north, and the whirlwind sweeping all before it, says, "My wife died in the evening and I did in the morning as I was commanded".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:10
verses.text: For the Lord had previously told him that in that day he should open his mouth, and speak, and no longer keep silence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:11
verses.text: Mark well, that while his wife was living he was not at liberty to admonish the people.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:12
verses.text: His wife died, the bond of wedlock was broken, and without the least hesitation he constantly devoted himself to the prophetic office.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:13
verses.text: For he who was called being free, is truly the Lord's bondservant.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:14
verses.text: I do not deny the blessedness of widows who remain such after their baptism; nor do I disparage those wives who maintain their chastity in wedlock; but as they attain a greater reward with God than married women who pay the marriage due, let widows themselves be content to give the preference to virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 33:15
verses.text: For if a chastity which comes too late, when the glow of bodily pleasure is no longer felt, makes them feel superior to married women, why should they not acknowledge themselves inferior to perpetual virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:2
verses.text: All that goes for nothing, says Jovinianus, because even bishops, priests, and deacons, husbands of one wife, and having children, were appointed by the Apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:3
verses.text: Just as the Apostle says he has no commandment respecting virgins, and yet gives his advice, as one who had obtained mercy from the Lord, and is anxious throughout the whole discussion to give virginity the preference over marriage, and advises what he does not venture to command, lest he seem to lay a snare, and to put a heavier burden upon man's nature than it can bear; so also in establishing the constitution of the Church, inasmuch as the elements of the early Church were drawn from the Gentiles, he made the rules for fresh believers somewhat lighter that they might not in alarm shrink from keeping them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:4
verses.text: Then, again, the Apostles and elders wrote letters from Jerusalem that no heavier burden should be laid on Gentile believers than that they should keep themselves from idolatry, and from fornication, and from things strangled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:5
verses.text: As though they were providing for infant children, they gave them milk to drink, not solid food.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:6
verses.text: Nor did they lay down rules for continence, nor hint at virginity, nor urge to fasting, nor repeat the directions given in the Gospel to the Apostles, not to have two tunics, nor scrip, nor money in their girdles, nor staff in their hand, nor shoes on their feet.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:7
verses.text: And they certainly did not bid them, if they wished to be perfect, go and sell all that they had and give to the poor, and "come follow me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:8
verses.text: For if the young man who boasted of having done all that the law enjoins, when he heard this went away sorrowful, because he had great possessions, and the Pharisees derided an utterance such as this from our Lord's lips: how much more would the vast multitude of Gentiles, whose highest virtue consisted in not plundering another's goods, have repudiated the obligation of perpetual chastity and continence, when they were told in the letter to keep themselves from idols, and from fornication, seeing that fornication was heard of among them, and such fornication as was not "even among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:9
verses.text: But the very choice of a bishop makes for me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:10
verses.text: For he does not say: Let a bishop be chosen who marries one wife and begets children; but who marries one wife, and has his children in subjection and well disciplined.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:11
verses.text: You surely admit that he is no bishop who during his episcopate begets children.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:12
verses.text: The reverse is the case—if he be discovered, he will not be bound by the ordinary obligations of a husband, but will be condemned as an adulterer.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:13
verses.text: Either permit priests to perform the work of marriage with the result that virginity and marriage are on a par: or if it is unlawful for priests to touch their wives, they are so far holy in that they imitate virgin chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:14
verses.text: But something more follows.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:15
verses.text: A layman, or any believer, cannot pray unless he abstain from sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:16
verses.text: Now a priest must always offer sacrifices for the people: he must therefore always pray.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:17
verses.text: And if he must always pray, he must always be released from the duties of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:18
verses.text: For even under the old law they who used to offer sacrifices for the people not only remained in their houses, but purified themselves for the occasion by separating from their wives, nor would they drink wine or strong drink which are wont to stimulate lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:19
verses.text: That married men are elected to the priesthood, I do not deny: the number of virgins is not so great as that of the priests required.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:20
verses.text: Does it follow that because all the strongest men are chosen for the army, weaker men should not be taken as well? All cannot be strong.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:21
verses.text: If an army were constituted of strength only, and numbers went for nothing, the feebler men might be rejected.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:22
verses.text: As it is, men of second or third-rate strength are chosen, that the army may have its full numerical complement.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:23
verses.text: How is it, then, you will say, that frequently at the ordination of priests a virgin is passed over, and a married man taken? Perhaps because he lacks other qualifications in keeping with virginity, or it may be that he is thought a virgin, and is not: or there may be a stigma on his virginity, or at all events virginity itself makes him proud, and while he plumes himself on mere bodily chastity, he neglects other virtues; he does not cherish the poor: he is too fond of money.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:24
verses.text: It sometimes happens that a man has a gloomy visage, a frowning brow, a walk as though he were in a solemn procession, and so offends the people, who, because they have no fault to find with his life, hate his mere dress and gait.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:25
verses.text: Many are chosen not out of affection for themselves, but out of hatred for another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:26
verses.text: In most cases the election is won by mere simplicity, while the shrewdness and discretion of another candidate elicit opposition as though they were evils.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:27
verses.text: Sometimes the judgement of the commoner people is at fault, and in testing the qualities of the priesthood, the individual inclines to his own character, with the result that he looks not so much for a good candidate as for one like himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:28
verses.text: Not unfrequently it happens that married men, who form the larger portion of the people, in approving married candidates seem to approve themselves, and it does not occur to them that the mere fact that they prefer a married person to a virgin is evidence of their inferiority to virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:29
verses.text: What I am going to say will perhaps offend many.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:30
verses.text: Yet I will say it, and good men will not be angry with me, because they will not feel the sting of conscience.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:31
verses.text: Sometimes it is the fault of the bishops, who choose into the ranks of the clergy not the best, but the cleverest, men, and think the more simple as well as innocent ones incapable; or, as though they were distributing the offices of an earthly service, they give posts to their kindred and relations; or they listen to the dictates of wealth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:32
verses.text: And, worse than all, they give promotion to the clergy who besmear them with flattery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:33
verses.text: To take the other view, if the Apostle's meaning be that marriage is necessary in a bishop, the Apostle himself ought not to have been a bishop, for he said, "Yet I would that all men were even as I myself".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:34
verses.text: And John will be thought unworthy of this rank, and all the virgins, and the continent, the fairest gems that give grace and ornament to the Church.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:35
verses.text: Bishop, priest, and deacon, are not honourable distinctions, but names of offices.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 34:36
verses.text: And we do not read:"If a man seeketh the office of a bishop, he desireth a good degree," but, "he desireth a good work," because by being placed in the higher order an opportunity is afforded him, if he choose to avail himself of it, for the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:2
verses.text: "The bishop, then, must be without reproach, so that he is the slave of no vice: "the husband of one wife," that is, in the past, not in the present; "sober," orbetter, as it is in the Greek, "vigilant," that is νηφάλεον; "chaste," for that is themeaning of σὼφρονα;"distinguished," both by chastity and conduct: "hospitable," so that he imitates Abraham, and with strangers, nay rather in strangers, entertains Christ; "apt to teach," for it profits nothing to enjoy the consciousness of virtue, unless a man be able to instruct the people intrusted to him, so that he can exhort in doctrine, and refute the gainsayers;"not a drunkard," for he who is constantly in the Holy of Holies and offers sacrifices, will not drink wine and strong drink, since wine is a luxury.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:3
verses.text: If a bishop drink at all, let it be in such a way that no one will know whether he has drunk or not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:4
verses.text: "No striker," that is,a striker of men's consciences, for the Apostle is not pointing out what a boxer, but a pontiff ought not to do.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:5
verses.text: He directly teaches what he ought to do: "but gentle, not contentious, no lover of money, one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection with all chastity".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:6
verses.text: See what chastity is required in a bishop! If his child be unchaste, he himself cannot be a bishop, and he offends God in the same way as didEli the priest, who had indeed rebuked his sons, but because he had not put away the offenders, fell backwards and died before the lamp of God went out".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:7
verses.text: Women in like manner must be chaste," and so on.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:8
verses.text: In every grade, and in both sexes, chastity has the chief place.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:9
verses.text: You see then that the blessedness of a bishop, priest, or deacon, does not lie in the fact that they are bishops, priests, or deacons, but in their having the virtues which their names and offices imply.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:10
verses.text: Otherwise, if a deacon be holier than his bishop, his lower grade will not give him a worse standing with Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:11
verses.text: If it were so, Stephen the deacon, the first to wear the martyr's crown, would be less in the kingdom of heaven than many bishops, and than Timothy and Titus, whom I venture to make neither inferior nor yet superior to him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 35:12
verses.text: Just as in the legions of the army there are generals, tribunes, centurions, javelin-men, and light-armed troops, common soldiers, and companies, but once the battle begins, all distinctions of rank are dropped, and the one thing looked for is valour: so too in this camp and in this battle, in which we contend against devils, not names but deeds are needed: and under the true commander, Christ, not the man who has the highest title has the greatest fame, but he who is the bravest warrior.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:2
verses.text: But you will say: "If everybody were a virgin, what would become of the human race"? Like shall here beget like.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:3
verses.text: If everyone were a widow, or continent in marriage, how will mortal men be propagated? Upon this principle there will be nothing at all for fear that something else may cease to exist.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:4
verses.text: To put a case: if all men were philosophers, there would be no husbandmen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:5
verses.text: Why speak of husbandmen? there would be no orators, no lawyers, no teachers of the other professions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:6
verses.text: If all men were leaders, what would become of the soldiers? If all were the head, whose head would they be called, when there were no other members? You are afraid that if the desire for virginity were general there would be no prostitutes, no adulteresses, no wailing infants in town or country.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:7
verses.text: Every day the blood of adulterers is shed, adulterers are condemned, and lust is raging and rampant in the very presence of the laws and the symbols of authority and the courts of justice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:8
verses.text: Be not afraid that all will become virgins: virginity is a hard matter, and therefore rare, because it is hard: "Many are called, few chosen".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:9
verses.text: Many begin, few persevere.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:10
verses.text: And so the reward is great for those who have persevered.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:11
verses.text: If all were able to be virgins, our Lord would never have said:"He that is able to receive it, let him receive it:" and the Apostle would not have hesitated to give his advice,—"Now concerning virgins I have no commandment of the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:12
verses.text: Why then, you will say, were the organs of generation created, and why were we so fashioned by the all-wise creator, that we burn for one another, and long for natural intercourse? To reply is to endanger our modesty: we are, as it were, between two rocks, theSymplegades of necessity and virtue, on either side; and must make shipwreck of either our sense of shame, or of the cause we defend: If we reply to your suggestions, shame covers our face.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:13
verses.text: If shame secures silence, in a manner we seem to desert our post, and to leave the ground clear to the raging foe.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:14
verses.text: Yet it is better, as the story goes, to shut our eyes and fight like theblindfold gladiators, than not to repel with the shield of truth the darts aimed at us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:15
verses.text: I can indeed say: "Our hinder parts which are banished from sight, and the lower portions of the abdomen, which perform the functions of nature, are the Creator's work".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:16
verses.text: But inasmuch as the physical conformation of the organs of generation testifies to difference of sex, I shall briefly reply: Are we never then to forego lust, for fear that we may have members of this kind for nothing? Why then should a husband keep himself from his wife? Why should a widow persevere in chastity, if we were only born to live like beasts? Or what harm does it do me if another man lies with my wife? For as the teeth were made for chewing, and the food masticated passes into the stomach, and a man is not blamed for giving my wife bread: similarly if it was intended that the organs of generation should always be performing their office, when my vigour is spent let another take my place, and, if I may so speak, let my wife quench her burning lust where she can.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:17
verses.text: But what does the Apostle mean by exhorting to continence, if continence be contrary to nature? What does our Lord mean when He instructs us in the various kinds of eunuchs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:18
verses.text: Surely the Apostle who bids us emulate his own chastity, must be asked, if we are to be consistent, Why are you like other men, Paul? Why are you distinguished from the female sex by a beard, hair, and other peculiarities of person? How is it that you have not swelling bosoms, and are not broad at the hips, narrow at the chest? Your voice is rugged, your speech rough, your eyebrows more shaggy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:19
verses.text: To no purpose you have all these manly qualities, if you forego the embraces of women.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:20
verses.text: I am compelled to say something and become a fool: but you have forced me to dare to speak.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:21
verses.text: Our Lord and Saviour, Who though He was in the form of God, condescended to take the form of a servant, and became obedient to the Father even unto death, yea the death of the cross—what necessity was there for Him to be born with members which He was not going to use? He certainly was circumcised to manifest His sex.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:22
verses.text: Why did he cause John the Apostle and John the Baptist to make themselves eunuchs through love of Him, after causing them to be born men? Let us then who believe in Christ follow His example.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:23
verses.text: And if we knew Him after the flesh, let us no longer know Him according to the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:24
verses.text: The substance of our resurrection bodies will certainly be the same as now, though of higher glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:25
verses.text: For the Saviour after His descent into hell had so far the selfsame body in which He was crucified, that He showed the disciples the marks of the nails in His hands and the wound in His side.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:26
verses.text: Moreover, if we deny the identity of His body because He entered though the doors were shut, and this is not a property of human bodies, we must deny also that Peter and the Lord had real bodies because they walked upon the water, which is contrary to nature".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:27
verses.text: In the resurrection of the dead they will neither marry nor be given in marriage, but will be like the angels".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:28
verses.text: What others will hereafter be in heaven, that virgins begin to be on earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 36:29
verses.text: If likeness to the angels is promised us (and there is no difference of sex among the angels), we shall either be of no sex as are the angels, or at all events which is clearly proved, though we rise from the dead in our own sex, we shall not perform the functions of sex.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:2
verses.text: But why do we argue, and why are we eager to frame a clever and victorious reply to our opponent? "Old things have passed away, behold all things have become new".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:3
verses.text: I will run through the utterances of the Apostles, and as to the instances afforded by Solomon I added short expositions to facilitate their being understood, so now I will go over the passages bearing on Christian purity and continence, and will make of many proofs a connected series.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:4
verses.text: By this method I shall succeed in omitting nothing relating to chastity, and shall avoid being tediously long.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:5
verses.text: Amongst other passages, Paul the Apostle writes to the Romans: "What fruit then had ye at that time in the things whereof ye are now ashamed? for the end of those things is death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:6
verses.text: But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto sanctification, and the end eternal life".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:7
verses.text: I suppose too that the end of marriage is death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:8
verses.text: But the compensating fruit of sanctification, fruit belonging either to virginity or to continence, is eternal life.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:9
verses.text: And afterwards: "Wherefore, my brethren, ye also were made dead to the law through the body of Christ; that ye should be joined to another, even to him who was raised from the dead, that we might bring forth fruit unto God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:10
verses.text: For when we were in the flesh, the sinful passions, which were through the law, wrought in our members to bring forth fruit unto death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:11
verses.text: But now we have been discharged from the law, having died to that wherein we were holden; so that we serve in newness of the Spirit, and not in oldness of the letter".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:12
verses.text: "When," he says, "we were in the flesh, and not in the newness of the Spirit but in the oldness of the letter," we did those things which pertained to the flesh, and bore fruit unto death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:13
verses.text: But now because we are dead to the law, through the body of Christ, let us bear fruit to God, that we may belong to Him who rose from the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:14
verses.text: And elsewhere, having previously said, "I know that the law is spiritual," and having discussed at some length the violence of the flesh which frequently drives us to do what we would not, he at last continues: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me out of the body of this death? I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:15
verses.text: And again, "So then I myself with the mind serve the law of God; but with the flesh the law of sin".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:16
verses.text: And, "There is therefore now no condemnation to them that are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:17
verses.text: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus made me free from the law of sin and death".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:18
verses.text: And more clearly in what follows he teaches that Christians do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit: "For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the spirit the things of the spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:19
verses.text: For the mind of the flesh is death; but the mind of the spirit is life and peace: because the mind of the flesh is enmity against God; for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed can it be: and they that are in the flesh cannot please God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:20
verses.text: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you," and so on to where he says, "So then, brethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live after the flesh: for if ye live after the flesh, ye must die; but if by the spirit ye mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:21
verses.text: For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:22
verses.text: If the wisdom of the flesh is enmity against God, and they who are in the flesh cannot please God, I think that they who perform the functions of marriage love the wisdom of the flesh, and therefore are in the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:23
verses.text: The Apostle being desirous to withdraw us from the flesh and to join us to the Spirit, says afterwards:"I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, which is your reasonable service.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:24
verses.text: And be not fashioned according to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is the good and acceptable and perfect will of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:25
verses.text: For I say, through the grace that was given me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but to think according to chastity" (not soberly as the Latin versions badly render), but "think," he says, "according to chastity," for the Greek words are ἐις τὸ σωφρονεὶν.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:26
verses.text: Let us consider what the Apostle says: "Be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is the good and acceptable and perfect will of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:27
verses.text: What he says is something like this—God indeed permits marriage, He permits second marriages, and if necessary, prefers even third marriages to fornication and adultery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:28
verses.text: But we who ought to present our bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, which is our reasonable service, should consider, not what God permits, but what He wishes: that we may prove what is the good and acceptable and perfect will of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:29
verses.text: It follows that what He merely permits is neither good, nor acceptable, nor perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:30
verses.text: And he gives his reasons for this advice: "Knowing the season, that now it is high time for you to awake out of sleep: for now is salvation nearer to us than when we first believed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:31
verses.text: The night is far spent, and the day is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:32
verses.text: And lastly: "Put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make not provision for the flesh, to fulfil the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:33
verses.text: God's will is one thing, His indulgence another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:34
verses.text: Whence, writing to the Corinthians, he says, "I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal, even as unto babes in Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:35
verses.text: I have fed you with milk, and not with meat: for hitherto ye were not able to bear it, neither yet now are ye able.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:36
verses.text: For ye are yet carnal".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:37
verses.text: He who is in the merely animal state, and does not receive the things pertaining to the Spirit of God (for he is foolish, and cannot understand them, because they are spiritually discerned), he is not fed with the food of perfect chastity, but with the coarse milk of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:38
verses.text: As through man came death, so also through man came the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:39
verses.text: As in Adam we all die, so in Christ we shall all be made alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:40
verses.text: Under the law we served the old Adam, under the Gospel let us serve the new Adam.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:41
verses.text: For the first man Adam was made a living soul, the last Adam was made a quickening spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:42
verses.text: "The first man is of the earth, earthy: the second man is of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:43
verses.text: As is the earthy, such are they also that are earthy: and as is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:44
verses.text: And as we have borne the image of the earthy, we shall also bear the image of the heavenly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:45
verses.text: Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the Kingdom of God; neither doth corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:46
verses.text: This is so clear that no explanation can make it clearer: "Flesh and blood," he says, "cannot inherit the Kingdom of God, neither doth corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:47
verses.text: If corruption attaches to all intercourse, and incorruption is characteristic of chastity, the rewards of chastity cannot belong to marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:48
verses.text: "For we know that if the earthly house of this tabernacle be dissolved, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal, in the heavens.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:49
verses.text: For verily in this we groan, longing to be clothed upon with our habitation which is from heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:50
verses.text: We are willing to be absent from the body, and to be at home with the Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:51
verses.text: Wherefore also we make it our aim, whether in the body, or out of the body, to be well-pleasing unto God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:52
verses.text: And by way of more fully explaining what he did not wish them to be he says elsewhere: "I espoused you to one husband, that I might present you as a pure virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:53
verses.text: But if you choose to apply the words to the whole Assembly of believers, and in this betrothal to Christ include both married women, and the twice-married, and widows, and virgins, that also makes for us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:54
verses.text: For whilst he invites all to chastity and to the reward of virginity, he shows that virginity is more excellent than all these conditions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:55
verses.text: And again writing to the Galatians he says: "Because by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:56
verses.text: Among the works of the law is marriage, and accordingly under it they are cursed who have no children.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 37:57
verses.text: And if under the Gospel it is permitted to have children, it is one thing to make a concession to weakness, another to hold out rewards to virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:2
verses.text: Something else I will say to my friends who marry and after long chastity and continence begin to burn and are as wanton as the brutes: "Are ye so foolish? having begun in the Spirit, are ye now perfected in the flesh? Did ye suffer so many things in vain?" If the Apostle in the case of some persons loosens the cords of continence, and lets them have a slack rein, he does so on account of the infirmity of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:3
verses.text: This is the enemy he has in view when he once more says: "Walk by the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfill the lust of the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:4
verses.text: For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:5
verses.text: It is unnecessary now to speak of the works of the flesh: it would be tedious, and he who chooses can easily gather them from the letter of the Apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:6
verses.text: I will only speak of the Spirit and its fruits, love, joy, peace, long suffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, meekness,continence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:7
verses.text: All the virtues of the Spirit are supported and protected by continence, which is as it were their solid foundation and crowning point.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:8
verses.text: Against such there is no law".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:9
verses.text: And they that are of Christ have crucified their flesh with the passions and the lusts thereof.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:10
verses.text: If we live by the Spirit, by the Spirit let us also walk".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:11
verses.text: Why do we who with Christ have crucified our flesh and its passions and desires again desire to do the things of the flesh? "Whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:12
verses.text: For he that soweth unto his own flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth unto the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap eternal life".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:13
verses.text: I think that he who has a wife, so long as he reverts to the practice in question, that Satan may not tempt him, is sowing to the flesh and not to the Spirit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:14
verses.text: And he who sows to the flesh (the words are not mine, but the Apostle's) reaps corruption.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:15
verses.text: God the Father chose us in Christ before the foundation of the world, that we might be holy and without spot before Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:16
verses.text: We walked in the lusts of the flesh, doing the desires of the flesh and of the thoughts, and were children of wrath, even as the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:17
verses.text: But now He has raised us up with Him, and made us to sit with Him in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus, that we may put away according to our former manner of life the old man, which is corrupt according to the lusts of deceit, and that blessing may be applied to us which so finely concludes the mystical Epistle to the Ephesians:"Grace be with all them that love our Lord Jesus Christ in uncorruptness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:18
verses.text: "For our citizenship is in heaven; from whence also we wait for a Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ: who shall fashion anew the body of our humiliation, that it may be conformed to the body of his glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:19
verses.text: Whatsoever things then are true, whatsoever are chaste, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things pertain to purity, let us join ourselves to these, let us follow these.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:20
verses.text: Christ hath reconciled us in his body to God the Father through his death, and has presented us holy and without spot, and without blame before himself: in whom we have been also circumcised, not with the circumcision made with hands, to the spoiling of the body of the flesh, but with the circumcision of Christ, having been buried with him in baptism, wherein also we rose with him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:21
verses.text: If then we have risen with Christ, let us seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God; let us set our affections on things above, not upon the things that are upon the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:22
verses.text: For we are dead, and our life is hid with Christ in God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:23
verses.text: When Christ our life shall appear, then we also shall appear with him in glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:24
verses.text: No soldier on service entangleth himself in the affairs of this life; that he may please him who enrolled him as a soldier.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 38:25
verses.text: For the grace of God hath appeared, bringing salvation to all men, instructing us, to the intent that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live purely and righteously and godly in this present world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:2
verses.text: The day would not be long enough were I to attempt to relate all that the Apostle enjoins concerning purity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:3
verses.text: These things are those concerning which our Lord said to the Apostles: "I have yet many things to say unto you, but ye cannot bear them now.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:4
verses.text: Howbeit, when he, the Spirit of truth, is come, he shall guide you into all the truth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:5
verses.text: After the crucifixion of Christ, we find in the Acts of the Apostles that one house, that of Philip the Evangelist, produced four virgin daughters, to the end that Caesarea, where the Gentile Church had been consecrated in the person of Cornelius the centurion, might afford an illustration of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:6
verses.text: And whereas our Lord said in the Gospel: "The law and the prophets were until John," they because they were virgins are related to have prophesied even after John.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:7
verses.text: For they could not be bound by the law of the Old Testament, who had shone with the brightness of virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:8
verses.text: Let us pass on to James, who was called the brother of the Lord, a man of such sanctity and righteousness, and distinguished by so rigid and perpetual a virginity, that evenJosephus, the Jewish historian, relates that the overthrow of Jerusalem was due to his death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:9
verses.text: He, the first bishop of the Church at Jerusalem, which was composed of Jewish believers, to whom Paul went, accompanied by Titus and Barnabas, says in his Epistle: "Be not deceived, my beloved brethren.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:10
verses.text: Every good gift and every perfect boon is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no difference, neither shadow that is cast by turning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:11
verses.text: Of his own will he brought us forth by the word of truth, that we should be a kind of first-fruits of his creatures".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:12
verses.text: Himself a virgin, he teaches virginity in a mystery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:13
verses.text: Every perfect gift cometh down from above, where marriage is unknown; and it cometh down, not from any one you please, but from the Father of lights, Who says to the apostles, "Ye are the light of the world;" with Whom there is no difference of Jew, or Gentile, nor does that shadow which was the companion of the law, trouble those who have believed from among the nations; but with His word He begat us, and with the word of truth, because some shadow, image, and likeness of truth went before in the law, that we might be the first-fruits of His creatures.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:14
verses.text: And as He who was Himself thefirst begotten from the dead has raised all that have died in Him: so He who was a virgin, consecrated the first-fruits of His virgins in His own virgin self.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:15
verses.text: Let us also consider what Peter thinks of the calling of the Gentiles:"Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to his great mercy begat us again unto a living hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, unto an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserved in heaven for you, who by the power of God are guarded through faith unto a salvation ready to be revealed in the last time".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:16
verses.text: Where we read of an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, prepared in heaven and reserved for the last time, and of the hope of eternal life when they will neither marry, nor be given in marriage, there, in other words, the privileges of virginity are described.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:17
verses.text: For he shows as much in what follows: "Wherefore girding up the loins of your mind, be sober and set your hope perfectly on the grace that is to be brought unto you at the revelation of Jesus Christ; as children of obedience, not fashioning yourselves according to your former lusts in the time of your ignorance; but like as he which called you is holy, be ye yourselves also holy in all manner of living; because it is written, ye shall be holy; for I am holy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:18
verses.text: For we were not redeemed with contemptible things, with silver or gold; but with the precious blood of a lamb without spot, Jesus Christ, that we might purify our souls in obedience to the truth, having been begotten again not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, through the word of God, who liveth and abideth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:19
verses.text: And as living stones let us be built up a spiritual house, an holy priesthood offering up spiritual sacrifices through Christ our Lord.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:20
verses.text: For we are an elect race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for God's own possession.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:21
verses.text: Christ died for us in the flesh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:22
verses.text: Let us arm ourselves with the same conversation as did Christ; for he that hath suffered in the flesh hath ceased from sin; that we should no longer live the rest of our time in the flesh to the lusts of men, but to the will of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:23
verses.text: For the time past is sufficient for us when we walked in lasciviousness, lusts, and other vices.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:24
verses.text: Great and precious are the promises attaching to virginity which He has given us,that through it we may become partakers of the divine nature, having escaped from the corruption that is in the world through lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:25
verses.text: The Lord knoweth how to deliver the godly out of temptation, and to keep the unrighteous under punishment unto the day of judgement, but chiefly them that walk after the flesh in the lust of defilement, and despise dominion, daring, self-willed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:26
verses.text: For they, as beasts of burden, without reason, think only of their belly and their lusts, railers who shall in their corruption be destroyed, and shall receive the reward of iniquity: men that count unrighteousness delight, spots and blemishes, thinking of nothing but their pleasures; having eyes full of adultery and insatiable lust, deceiving souls not yet strengthened by the love of Christ.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:27
verses.text: For they utter swelling words and easily snare the unlearned with the seduction of the flesh; promising them liberty while they themselves are the slaves of vice, luxury, and corruption.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:28
verses.text: For of what a man is overcome, of the same is he also brought into bondage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:29
verses.text: But if, after they had escaped the defilements of the world through the knowledge of our Saviour Jesus Christ, they are again overcome by that which they before overcame, the last state is become worse with them than the first.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:30
verses.text: And it were better for them not to have known the way of righteousness, than, after knowing it, to turn back and forsake the holy commandment delivered unto them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:31
verses.text: And it has happened unto them according to the true proverb, the dog hath turned to his own vomit again, and the sow that had washed to wallowing in the mire".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:32
verses.text: I have hesitated, for fear of being tedious, to quote the whole passage of the second Epistle of Peter, and have merely shown that the Holy Spirit in prophecy foretold the teachers of this time and their heresy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 39:33
verses.text: Lastly, he more clearly denotes them, saying, "In the last days seducing mockers shall come, walking after their own lusts".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:2
verses.text: The Apostle has described Jovinianus speaking with swelling cheeks and nicely balancing his inflated utterances, promising heavenly liberty, when he himself is the slave of vice and self-indulgence, a dog returning to his vomit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:3
verses.text: For although he boasts of being a monk, he has exchanged his dirty tunic, bare feet, common bread, and drink of water, for a snowy dress, sleek skin, honey-wine and dainty dishes, for the sauces ofApicius andPaxamus, for baths and rubbings, and for the cook-shops.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:4
verses.text: Is it not clear that he prefers his belly to Christ, and thinks his ruddy complexion worth the kingdom of heaven? And yet that handsome monk so fat and sleek, and of bright appearance, who always walks with the air of a bridegroom, must either marry a wife if he is to show that virginity and marriage are equal: or if he does not marry one, it is useless for him to bandy words with us when his acts are on our side.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:5
verses.text: And John agrees with this almost to the letter: "Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:6
verses.text: If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:7
verses.text: For all that is in the world is the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of this life, which is not of the Father, but is of the world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:8
verses.text: And, "The world passeth away, and the lust thereof: but he that doeth the will of God abideth for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:9
verses.text: A new commandment have I written unto you, which thing is true both in Christ and in you; because the darkness is passing away, and the true light already shineth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:10
verses.text: And again,"Beloved, now are we the children of God, and it is not yet made manifest what we shall be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:11
verses.text: But we know that, if he shall be manifested, we shall be like him: for we shall see him even as he is.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:12
verses.text: And every one that hath this hope purifieth himself, even as he is pure.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:13
verses.text: Herein is our love made perfect, if we have boldness in the day of judgement: that as he is, even so may we be in this world".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:14
verses.text: The Epistle of Jude also expresses nearly the same: "Hating even the garment spotted by the flesh".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:15
verses.text: Let us read the Apocalypse of John, and we shall there find the Lamb upon Mount Sion, and with Him "a hundred and forty-four thousand of them that were sealed, having His name and the name of His Father written in their foreheads, who sing a new song, and no one can sing that song save they who have been redeemed out of the earth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:16
verses.text: These are they who have not defiled themselves with women, for they continued virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:17
verses.text: These follow the Lamb whithersoever He goeth: for they were redeemed from among men, first-fruits to God and to the Lamb, and in their mouth was found no guile, and they are without spot".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:18
verses.text: Out of each tribe, the tribe of Dan excepted, the place of which is taken by the tribe of Levi, twelve thousand virgins who have been sealed are spoken of as future believers, who have not defiled themselves with women.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:19
verses.text: And that we may not suppose the reference to be to those who know not harlots, he immediately added: "For they continued virgins".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:20
verses.text: Whereby he shows that all who have not preserved their virginity, in comparison of pure and angelic chastity and of our Lord Jesus Christ Himself, are defiled".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:21
verses.text: These are they who sing a new song which no man can sing except him that is a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:22
verses.text: These are first-fruits unto God and unto the Lamb, and are without blemish".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:23
verses.text: If virgins are first-fruits, it follows that widows and the continent in marriage, come after the first-fruits, that is, are in the second and third rank: nor can a lost people be saved unless it offer such sacrifices of chastity to God, and with pure victims reconcile the spotless Lamb.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:24
verses.text: It would be endless work to explain the Gospel mystery of the ten virgins, five of whom were wise and five foolish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:25
verses.text: All I say now is, that as mere virginity without other works does not save, so all works without virginity, purity, continence, chastity, are imperfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:26
verses.text: And we shall not be hindered in the least from taking this view by the objection of our opponent that our Lord was at Cana of Galilee, and joined in the marriage festivities when He turned water into wine.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:27
verses.text: I shall very briefly reply, that He Who was circumcised on the eighth day, and for Whom a pair of turtle-doves and two young pigeons were offered on the day of purification, like others before He suffered, shewed His approval of Jewish custom, that He might not seem to give His enemies just cause for putting Him to death on the pretext that He destroyed the law and condemned nature.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:28
verses.text: And even this was done for our sakes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:29
verses.text: For by going once to a marriage, He taught that men should marry only once.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:30
verses.text: Moreover, at that time it was possible to injure virginity if marriage were not placed next to it, and the purity of widowhood in the third rank.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:31
verses.text: But now when heretics are condemning wedlock, and despise the ordinance of God, we gladly hear anything he may say in praise of marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 40:32
verses.text: For the Church does not condemn marriage, but makes it subordinate; nor does she reject it, but regulates it; for she knows, as was said before, that in a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and earthenware; and that some are to honour, some to dishonour; and that whoever cleanses himself will be a vessel of honour, necessary, prepared for every good work.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:2
verses.text: I have given enough and more than enough illustrations from the divine writings of Christian chastity and angelic virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:3
verses.text: But as I understand that our opponent in his commentaries summons us to the tribunal of worldly wisdom, and we are told that views of this kind are never accepted in the world, and that our religion has invented a dogma against nature, I will quickly run through Greek and Roman and Foreign History, and will show that virginity ever took the lead of chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:4
verses.text: Fable relates that Atalanta, the virgin of Calydonian fame, lived for the chase and dwelt always in the woods; in other words that she did not set her heart on marriage with its troubles of pregnancy and of sickness, but upon the nobler life of freedom and chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:5
verses.text: Harpalyce too, a Thracian virgin, is described by the famous poet; and so isCamilia, queen of the Volsci, on whom, when she came to his assistance, Turnus had no higher praise which he could bestow than to call her a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:6
verses.text: "O Virgin, Glory of Italy!" And that famous daughter ofLeos, the lady of the brazen house, ever a virgin, is related to have freed her country from pestilence by her voluntary death: and the blood of the virginIphigenia is said to have calmed the stormy winds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:7
verses.text: What need to tell of the Sibyls of Erythrae and Cumae, and the eight others? for Varro asserts there were ten whose ornament was virginity, and divination the reward of their virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:8
verses.text: But if in the aeolian dialect "Sibyl" is represented by Θεοβούλη, we must understand that a knowledge of the Counsel of God is rightly attributed to virginity alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:9
verses.text: We read, too, that Cassandra and Chryseis, prophetesses of Apollo and Juno, were virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:10
verses.text: And there were innumerable priestesses of the Taurian Diana, and of Vesta.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:11
verses.text: One of these, Munitia, being suspected of unchastily was buried alive, which would be in my opinion an unjust punishment, unless the violation of virginity were considered a serious crime.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:12
verses.text: At all events how highly the Romans always esteemed virgins is clear from the fact that consuls and generals even in their triumphal chariots and bringing home the spoils of conquered nations, were wont to make way for them to pass.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:13
verses.text: And so did men of all ranks.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:14
verses.text: WhenClaudia, a Vestal Virgin, was suspected of unchastily, and a vessel containing the image of Cybele was aground in the Tiber, it is related that she, to prove her chastity, with her girdle drew the ship which a thousand men could not move.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:15
verses.text: Yet, asthe uncle of Lucan the poet says, it would have been better if this circumstance had decorated a chastity tried and proved, and had not pleaded in defence of a chastity equivocal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:16
verses.text: No wonder that we read such things of human beings, when heathen error also invented the virgin goddesses Minerva and Diana, and placed the Virgin among the twelve signs of the Zodiac, by means of which, as they suppose, the world revolves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:17
verses.text: It is a proof of the little esteem in which they held marriage that they did not even among the scorpions, centaurs, crabs, fishes, and capricorn, thrust in a husband and wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:18
verses.text: When the thirty tyrants of Athens had slain Phidon at the banquet, they commanded his virgin daughters to come to them, naked like harlots, and there upon the ground, red with their father's blood, to act the wanton.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:19
verses.text: For a little while they hid their grief, and then when they saw the revellers were intoxicated, going out on the plea of easing nature, they embraced one another and threw themselves into a well, that by death they might save their virginity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:20
verses.text: The virgin daughter of Demotion, chief of the Areopagites, having heard of the death of her betrothed,Leosthenes, who had originated the Lamian war, slew herself, for she declared that although in body she was a virgin, yet if she were compelled to accept another, she should regard him as her second husband, when she had given her heart to Leosthenes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:21
verses.text: So close a friendship long existed between Sparta and Messene that for the furtherance of certain religious rites they even exchanged virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:22
verses.text: Well, on one occasion when the men of Messene attempted to outrage fifty Lacedaemonian virgins, out of so many not one consented, but they all most gladly died in defence of their chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:23
verses.text: Whence there arose a long and grievous war, and in the long runMamertina was destroyed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:24
verses.text: Aristoclides, tyrant of Orchomenos, fell in love with a virgin of Stymphalus, and when after the death of her father she took refuge in the temple of Diana, and embraced the image of the goddess and could not be dragged thence by force, she was slain on the spot.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:25
verses.text: Her death caused such intense grief throughout Arcadia that the people took up arms and avenged the virgin's death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:26
verses.text: Aristomenes of Messene, a just man, at a time when the Lacedaemonians, whom he had conquered, were celebrating by night the festival called theHyacinthia, carried off from the sportive bands fifteen virgins, and fleeing all night at full speed got away from the Spartan territory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:27
verses.text: His companions wished to outrage them, but he admonished them to the best of his power not to do so, and when certain refused to obey, he slew them, and restrained the rest by fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:28
verses.text: The maidens were afterwards ransomed by their kinsmen, and on seeing Aristomenes condemned for murder would not return to their country until clasping the knees of the judges they beheld the protector of their chastity acquitted.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:29
verses.text: How shall we sufficiently praise the daughters of Scedasus at Leuctra in Boeotia? It is related that in the absence of their father they hospitably entertained two youths who were passing by, and who having drunk to excess violated the virgins in the course of the night.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:30
verses.text: Being unwilling to survive the loss of their virginity, the maidens inflicted deadly wounds on one another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:31
verses.text: Nor would it be right to omit mention of the Locrian virgins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:32
verses.text: They were sent to Ilium according to custom which had lasted for nearly a thousand years, and yet not one gave occasion to any idle tale or filthy rumour of virginity defiled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:33
verses.text: Could any one pass over in silence the seven virgins of Miletus who, when the Gauls spread desolation far and wide, that they might suffer no indignity at the hands of the enemy, escaped disgrace by death, and left to all virgins the lesson of their example—that noble minds care more for chastity than life? Nicanor having conquered and overthrown Thebes was himself overcome by a passion for one captive virgin, whose voluntary self-surrender he longed for.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:34
verses.text: A captive maid, he thought, must be only too glad.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:35
verses.text: But he found that virginity is dearer to the pure in heart than a kingdom, when with tears and grief he held her in his arms slain by her own hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 41:36
verses.text: Greek writers tell also of another Theban virgin who had been deflowered by a Macedonian foe, and who, hiding her grief for a while, slew the violator of her virginity as he slept, and then killed herself with the sword, so that she would neither live when her chastity was lost, nor die before she had avenged herself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:2
verses.text: To come to the Gymnosophists of India, the opinion is authoritatively handed down that Budda, the founder of their religion, had his birth through the side of a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:3
verses.text: And we need not wonder at this in the case of Barbarians when cultured Greece supposed that Minerva at her birth sprang from the head of Jove, and Father Bacchus from his thigh.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:4
verses.text: Speusippus also, Plato's nephew, andClearchus in his eulogy of Plato, andAnaxelides in the second book of his philosophy, relates that Perictione, the mother of Plato, was violated by an apparition of Apollo, and they agree in thinking that the prince of wisdom was born of a virgin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:5
verses.text: Timaeus writes that thevirgin daughter ofPythagoras was at the head of a band of virgins, and instructed them in chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:6
verses.text: Diodorus, the disciple of Socrates, is said to have had five daughters skilled in dialectics and distinguished for chastity, of whom a full account is given by Philo the master ofCarneades.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 42:7
verses.text: And mighty Rome cannot taunt us as though we had invented the story of the birth of our Lord and Saviour from a virgin; for the Romans believe that the founders of their city and race were the offspring of the virginIlia and of Mars.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:2
verses.text: Let these allusions to the virgins of the world, brief and hastily gathered from many histories, now suffice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:3
verses.text: I will proceed to married women who were reluctant to survive the decease or violent death of their husbands for fear they might be forced into a second marriage, and who entertained a marvellous affection for the only husbands they had.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:4
verses.text: This may teach us that second marriage was repudiated among the heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:5
verses.text: Dido, the sister of Pygmalion, having collected a vast amount of gold and silver, sailed to Africa, and there built Carthage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:6
verses.text: And when her hand was sought in marriage by Iarbas, king of Libya, she deferred the marriage for a while until her country was settled.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:7
verses.text: Not long after, having raised afuneral pyre to the memory of her former husband Sichaeus, she preferred to "burn rather than to marry".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:8
verses.text: Carthage was built by a woman of chastity, and its end was a tribute to the excellence of the virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 43:9
verses.text: For thewife of Hasdrubal, when the city was captured and set on fire, and she saw that she could not herself escape capture by the Romans, took her little children in either hand and leaped into the burning ruins of her house.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:2
verses.text: What need to tell of the wife ofNiceratus, who, not enduring to wrong her husband, inflicted death upon herself rather than subject herself to the lust of the thirty tyrants whom Lysander had set over conquered Athens?Artemisia, also, wife of Mausolus, is related to have been distinguished for chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:3
verses.text: Though she was queen of Caria, and is extolled by great poets and historians, no higher praise is bestowed upon her than that when her husband was dead she loved him as much as when he was alive, and built a tomb so great that even to the present day all costly sepulchres are called after his name, mausoleums.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:4
verses.text: Teuta, queen of the Illyrians, owed her long sway over brave warriors, and her frequent victories over Rome, to her marvellous chastity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:5
verses.text: The Indians and almost all the Barbarians have a plurality of wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:6
verses.text: It is a law with them that the favourite wife must be burned with her dead husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:7
verses.text: The wives therefore vie with one another for the husband's love, and the highest ambition of the rivals, and the proof of chastity, is to be considered worthy of death.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:8
verses.text: So then she that is victorious, having put on her former dress and ornaments, lies down beside the corpse, embracing and kissing it, and to the glory of chastity despises the flames which are burning beneath her.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:9
verses.text: I suppose that she who dies thus, wants no second marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:10
verses.text: The famous Alcibiades, the friend of Socrates, when Athens was conquered, fled to Pharnabazus, who took a bribe from Lysander the Lacedaemonian leader and ordered him to be slain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:11
verses.text: He was strangled, and when his head had been cut off it was sent to Lysander as proof of the murder, but the rest of his body lay unburied.
