verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:12
verses.text: His concubine, therefore, all alone, in defiance of the command of the cruel enemy, in the midst of strangers, and in the face of peril, gave him due burial, for she was ready to die for the dead man whom she had loved when living.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 44:13
verses.text: Let matrons, Christian matrons at all events, imitate the fidelity of concubines, and exhibit in their freedom what she in her captivity preserved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:2
verses.text: Strato, ruler of Sidon, thought of dying by his own hand, that he might not be the sport of the Persians, who were close by and whose alliance he had discarded for the friendship of the king of Egypt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:3
verses.text: But he drew back in terror, and eying the sword which he had seized, awaited in alarm the approach of the enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:4
verses.text: His wife, knowing that he must be immediately taken, wrested the weapon from his hand, and pierced his side.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:5
verses.text: When the body was properly laid out she lay down upon it in the agony of death, that she might not violate her virgin troth in the embraces of another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:6
verses.text: Xenophon, in describing the early years of the elder Cyrus, relates that when her husband Abradatas was slain, Panthea who had loved him intensely, placed herself beside the mangled body, then stabbed herself, and let her blood run into her husband's wounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:7
verses.text: Thequeen whom the king her husband had shewn naked and without her knowledge to his friend, thought she had good cause for slaying the king.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:8
verses.text: She judged that she was not beloved if it was possible for her to be exhibited to another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:9
verses.text: Rhodogune, daughter of Darius, after the death of her husband, put to death the nurse who was trying to persuade her to marry again.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:10
verses.text: Alcestis is related in story to have voluntarily died for Admetus, and Penelope's chastity is the theme of Homer's song.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 45:11
verses.text: Laodamia's praises are also sung by the poets, because, whenProtesilaus was slain at Troy, she refused to survive him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:2
verses.text: I may pass on to Roman women; and the first that I shall mention isLucretia, who would not survive her violated chastity, but blotted out the stain upon her person with her own blood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:3
verses.text: Duilius, the first Roman who won anaval triumph, took to wife a virgin, Bilia, of such extraordinary chastity that she was an example even to an age which held unchastity to be not merely vicious but monstrous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:4
verses.text: When he was grown old and feeble he was once in the course of a quarrel taunted with having bad breath.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:5
verses.text: In dudgeon he betook himself home, and on complaining to his wife that she had never told him of it so that he might remedy the fault, he received the reply that she would have done so, but she thought that all men had foul breath as he had.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:6
verses.text: In either case this chaste and noble woman deserves praise, whether she was not aware there was anything wrong with her husband, or if she patiently endured, and her husband discovered his unfortunate condition not by the disgust of a wife, but by the abuse of an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:7
verses.text: At all events the woman who marries a second time cannot say this.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:8
verses.text: Marcia, Cato's younger daughter, on being asked after the loss of her husband why she did not marry again, replied that she could not find a man who wanted her more than her money.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:9
verses.text: Her words teach us that men in choosing their wives look for riches rather than for chastity, and that many in marrying use not their eyes but their fingers.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:10
verses.text: That must be an excellent thing which is won by avarice! When the same lady was mourning the loss of her husband, and the matrons asked what day would terminate her grief, she replied, "The same that terminates my life".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:11
verses.text: I imagine that a woman who thus followed her husband in heart and mind had no thought of marrying again.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:12
verses.text: Porcia, whomBrutus took to wife, was a virgin; Cato's wife,Marcia, was not a virgin; but Marcia went to and fro between Hortensius and Cato, and was quite content to live without Cato; whilePorcia could not live without Brutus; for women attach themselves closely to particular men, and to keep to one is a strong link in the chain of affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:13
verses.text: When a relative urged Annia to marry again (she was of full age and a goodly person), she answered, "I shall certainly not do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:14
verses.text: For, if I find a good man, I have no wish to be in fear of losing him: if a bad one, why must I put up with a bad husband after having had a good one?"Porcia the younger, on hearing a certain lady of good character, who had a second husband, praised in her house, replied, "A chaste and happy matron never marries more than once".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:15
verses.text: Marcella the elder, on being asked by her mother if she was glad she was married, answered, "So much so that I want nothing more".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:16
verses.text: Valeria, sister of the Messalas, when she lost her husband Servius, would marry no one else.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 46:17
verses.text: On being asked why not, she said that to her, her husband Servius was ever alive.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:2
verses.text: I feel that in giving this list of women I have said far more than is customary in illustrating a point, and that I might be justly censured by my learned reader.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:3
verses.text: But what am I to do when the women of our time press me with apostolic authority, and before the first husband is buried, repeat from morning to night the precepts which allow a second marriage? Seeing they despise the fidelity which Christian purity dictates, let them at least learn chastity from the heathen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:4
verses.text: A book On Marriage, worth its weight in gold, passes under the name ofTheophrastus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:5
verses.text: In it the author asks whether a wise man marries.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:6
verses.text: And after laying down the conditions—that the wife must be fair, of good character, and honest parentage, the husband in good health and of ample means, and after saying that under these circumstances a wise man sometimes enters the state of matrimony, he immediately proceeds thus: "But all these conditions are seldom satisfied in marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:7
verses.text: A wise man therefore must not take a wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:8
verses.text: For in the first place his study of philosophy will be hindered, and it is impossible for anyone to attend to his books and his wife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:9
verses.text: Matrons want many things, costly dresses, gold, jewels, great outlay, maid-servants, all kinds of furniture, litters and gilded coaches.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:10
verses.text: Then come curtain-lectures the livelong night: she complains that one lady goes out better dressed than she: that another is looked up to by all: 'I am a poor despised nobody at the ladies' assemblies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:11
verses.text: ' 'Why did you ogle that creature next door?' 'Why were you talking to the maid?' 'What did you bring from the market?' 'I am not allowed to have a single friend, or companion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:12
verses.text: ' She suspects that her husband's love goes the same way as her hate.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:13
verses.text: There may be in some neighbouring city the wisest of teachers; but if we have a wife we can neither leave her behind, nor take the burden with us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:14
verses.text: To support a poor wife, is hard: to put up with a rich one, is torture.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:15
verses.text: Notice, too, that in the case of a wife you cannot pick and choose: you must take her as you find her.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:16
verses.text: If she has a bad temper, or is a fool, if she has a blemish, or is proud, or has bad breath, whatever her fault may be—all this we learn after marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:17
verses.text: Horses, asses, cattle, even slaves of the smallest worth, clothes, kettles, wooden seats, cups, and earthenware pitchers, are first tried and then bought: a wife is the only thing that is not shown before she is married, for fear she may not give satisfaction.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:18
verses.text: Our gaze must always be directed to her face, and we must always praise her beauty: if you look at another woman, she thinks that she is out of favour.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:19
verses.text: She must be called my lady, her birth-day must be kept, we must swear by her health and wish that she may survive us, respect must be paid to the nurse, to the nursemaid, to the father's slave, to the foster-child, to the handsome hanger-on, to the curled darling who manages her affairs, and to the eunuch who ministers to the safe indulgence of her lust: names which are only a cloak for adultery.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:20
verses.text: Upon whomsoever she sets her heart, they must have her love though they want her not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:21
verses.text: If you give her the management of the whole house, you must yourself be her slave.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:22
verses.text: If you reserve something for yourself, she will not think you are loyal to her; but she will turn to strife and hatred, and unless you quickly take care, she will have the poison ready.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:23
verses.text: If you introduce old women, and soothsayers, and prophets, and vendors of jewels and silken clothing, you imperil her chastity; if you shut the door upon them, she is injured and fancies you suspect her.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:24
verses.text: But what is the good of even a careful guardian, when an unchaste wife cannot be watched, and a chaste one ought not to be? For necessity is but a faithless keeper of chastity, and she alone really deserves to be called pure, who is free to sin if she chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:25
verses.text: If a woman be fair, she soon finds lovers; if she be ugly, it is easy to be wanton.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:26
verses.text: It is difficult to guard what many long for.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:27
verses.text: It is annoying to have what no one thinks worth possessing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:28
verses.text: But the misery of having an ugly wife is less than that of watching a comely one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:29
verses.text: Nothing is safe, for which a whole people sighs and longs.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:30
verses.text: One man entices with his figure, another with his brains, another with his wit, another with his open hand.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:31
verses.text: Somehow, or sometime, the fortress is captured which is attacked on all sides.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:32
verses.text: Men marry, indeed, so as to get a manager for the house, to solace weariness, to banish solitude; but a faithful slave is a far better manager, more submissive to the master, more observant of his ways, than a wife who thinks she proves herself mistress if she acts in opposition to her husband, that is, if she does what pleases her, not what she is commanded.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:33
verses.text: But friends, and servants who are under the obligation of benefits received, are better able to wait upon us in sickness than a wife who makes us responsible for her tears (she will sell you enough to make a deluge for the hope of a legacy), boasts of her anxiety, but drives her sick husband to the distraction of despair.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:34
verses.text: But if she herself is poorly, we must fall sick with her and never leave her bedside.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:35
verses.text: Or if she be a good and agreeable wife (how rare a bird she is!), we have to share her groans in childbirth, and suffer torture when she is in danger.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:36
verses.text: A wise man can never be alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:37
verses.text: He has with him the good men of all time, and turns his mind freely wherever he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:38
verses.text: What is inaccessible to him in person he can embrace in thought.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:39
verses.text: And, if men are scarce, he converses with God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:40
verses.text: He is never less alone than when alone.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:41
verses.text: Then again, to marry for the sake of children, so that our name may not perish, or that we may have support in old age, and leave our property without dispute, is the height of stupidity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:42
verses.text: For what is it to us when we are leaving the world if another bears our name, when even a son does not all at once take his father's title, and there are countless others who are called by the same name.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:43
verses.text: Or what support in old age is he whom you bring up, and who may die before you, or turn out a reprobate? Or at all events when he reaches mature age, you may seem to him long in dying.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:44
verses.text: Friends and relatives whom you can judiciously love are better and safer heirs than those whom you must make your heirs whether you like it or not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 47:45
verses.text: Indeed, the surest way of having a good heir is to ruin your fortune in a good cause while you live, not to leave the fruit of your labour to be used you know not how".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:2
verses.text: When Theophrastus thus discourses, are there any of us, Christians, whose conversation is in heaven and who daily say "I long to be dissolved, and to be with Christ," whom he does not put to the blush? Shall a joint-heir of Christ really long for human heirs? And shall he desire children and delight himself in a long line of descendants, who will perhaps fall into the clutches of Antichrist, when we read thatMoses andSamuel preferred other men to their own sons, and did not count as their children those whom they saw to be displeasing to God? When Cicero after divorcing Terentia was requested byHirtius to marry his sister, he set the matter altogether on one side, and said that he could not possibly devote himself to a wife and to philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:3
verses.text: Meanwhile that excellent partner, who had herself drunk wisdom at Tully's fountains, married Sallust his enemy, and took for her third husband Messala Corvinus, and thus, as it were, passed through three degrees of eloquence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:4
verses.text: Socrates had two wives, Xantippe and Myron, grand-daughter of Aristides.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:5
verses.text: They frequently quarrelled, and he was accustomed to banter them for disagreeing about him, he being the ugliest of men, with snub nose, bald forehead, rough-haired, and bandy-legged.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:6
verses.text: At last they planned an attack upon him, and having punished him severely, and put him to flight, vexed him for a long time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:7
verses.text: On one occasion when he opposed Xantippe; who from above was heaping abuse upon him, the termagant soused him with dirty water, but he only wiped his head and said, "I knew that a shower must follow such thunder as that".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:8
verses.text: Metella, consort of L.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:9
verses.text: Sulla theFortunate (except in the matter of his wife) was openly unchaste.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:10
verses.text: It was the common talk of Athens, as I learnt in my youthful years when we soon pick up what is bad, and yet Sulla was in the dark, and first got to know the secrets of his household through the abuse of his enemies.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:11
verses.text: Cn.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:12
verses.text: Pompey had an impure wife Mucia, who was surrounded by eunuchs from Pontus and troops of the countrymen of Mithridates.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:13
verses.text: Others thought that he knew all and submitted to it; but a comrade told him during the campaign, and the conqueror of the whole world was dismayed at the sad intelligence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:14
verses.text: M.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:15
verses.text: Cato, the Censor, had a wife Actoria Paula, a woman of low origin, fond of drink, violent, and (who would believe it?) haughty to Cato.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:16
verses.text: I say this for fear anyone may suppose that in marrying a poor woman he has secured peace.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:17
verses.text: WhenPhilip king of Macedon, against whomDemosthenes thundered in his Philippics, was entering his bed-room as usual, his wife in a passion shut him out.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:18
verses.text: Finding himself excluded he held his tongue, and consoled himself for the insult by reading a tragic poem.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:19
verses.text: Gorgias the Rhetorician recited his excellent treatise on Concord to the Greeks, then at variance among themselves, at Olympia.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:20
verses.text: WhereuponMelanthius his enemy observed: "Here is a man who teaches us concord, and yet could not make concord between himself his wife, and maid-servant, three persons in one house".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:21
verses.text: The truth was that his wife envied the beauty of the girl, and drove the purest of men wild with daily quarrels.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:22
verses.text: Whole tragedies of Euripides are censures on women.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:23
verses.text: Hence Hermione says, "The counsels of evil women have beguiled me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:24
verses.text: In the semi-barbarous and remote cityLeptis it is the custom for a daughter-in-law on the second day to beg the loan of a jar from her mother-in-law.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:25
verses.text: The latter at once denies the request, and we see how true was the remark ofTerence, ambiguously expressed on purpose—"How is this? do all mothers-in-law hate their daughters-in-law?" We read of a certain Roman noble who, when his friends found fault with him for having divorced a wife, beautiful, chaste, and rich, put out his foot and said to them, "And the shoe before you looks new and elegant, yet no one but myself knows where it pinches".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:26
verses.text: Herodotus tells us that a woman puts off her modesty with her clothes.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:27
verses.text: And our own comic poet thinks the man fortunate who has never been married.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:28
verses.text: Why should I refer to Pasiphaë, Clytemnestra, and Eriphyle, the first of whom, the wife of a king and swimming in pleasure, is said to have lusted for a bull, the second to have killed her: husband for the sake of an adulterer, the third to have betrayed Amphiaraus, and to have preferred a gold necklace to the welfare of her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:29
verses.text: In all the bombast of tragedy and the overthrow of houses, cities, and kingdoms, it is the wives and concubines who stir up strife.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:30
verses.text: Parents take up arms against their children: unspeakable banquets are served: and on account of the rape of one wretched woman Europe and Asia are involved in a ten years' war.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:31
verses.text: We read of some who were divorced the day after they were married, and immediately married again.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:32
verses.text: Both husbands are to blame, both he who was so soon dissatisfied, and he who was so soon pleased.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:33
verses.text: Epicurus the patron of pleasure (thoughMetrodorus his disciple married Leontia) says that a wise man can seldom marry, because marriage has many drawbacks.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:34
verses.text: And as riches, honours, bodily health, and other things which we call indifferent, are neither good nor bad, but stand as it were midway, and become good and bad according to the use and issue, so wives stand on the border line of good and ill.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:35
verses.text: It is, moreover, a serious matter for a wise man to be in doubt whether he is going to marry a good or a bad woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:36
verses.text: Chrysippus ridiculously maintains that a wise man should marry, that he may not outrage Jupiter Gamelius and Genethlius.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:37
verses.text: For upon that principle the Latins would not marry at all, since they have no Jupiter who presides over marriage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 48:38
verses.text: But if, as he thinks, the life of men is determined by the names of gods, whoever chooses to sit will offend Jupiter Stator.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:2
verses.text: Aristotle and Plutarch and our Seneca have written treatises on matrimony, out of which we have already made some extracts and now add a few more.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:3
verses.text: "The love of beauty is the forgetting of reason and the near neighbour of madness; a foul blot little in keeping with a sound mind.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:4
verses.text: It confuses counsel, breaks high and generous spirits, draws away men from great thoughts to mean ones; it makes men querulous, ill-tempered, foolhardy, cruelly imperious, servile flatterers, good for nothing, at last not even for love itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:5
verses.text: For although in the intensity of passion it burns like a raging fire, it wastes much time through suspicions, tears, and complaints: it begets hatred of itself, and at last hates itself".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:6
verses.text: The course of love is laid bare in Plato's Phaedrus from beginning to end, and Lysias explains all its drawbacks—how it is led not by reason, but by frenzy, and in particular is a harsh gaoler over lovely wives.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:7
verses.text: Seneca, too, relates that he knew an accomplished man who before going out used to tie his wife's garter upon his breast, and could not bear to be absent from her for a quarter of an hour; and this pair would never take a drink unless husband and wife alternately put their lips to the cup; and they did other things just as absurd in the extravagant outbursts of their warm but blind affection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:8
verses.text: Their love was of honourable birth, but it grew out of all proportion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:9
verses.text: And it makes no difference how honourable may be the cause of a man's insanity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:10
verses.text: HenceXystus in his Sentences tells us that "He who too ardently loves his own wife is an adulterer".

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:11
verses.text: It is disgraceful to love another man's wife at all, or one's own too much.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:12
verses.text: A wise man ought to love his wife with judgment, not with passion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:13
verses.text: Let a man govern his voluptuous impulses, and not rush headlong into intercourse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:14
verses.text: There is nothing blacker than to love a wife as if she were an adulteress.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:15
verses.text: Men who say they have contracted marriage and are bringing up children, for the good of their country and of the race, should at least imitate the brutes, and not destroy their offspring in the womb; nor should they appear in the character of lovers, but of husbands.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:16
verses.text: In some cases marriage has grown out of adultery: and, shameful to relate! men have tried to teach their wives chastity after having taken their chastity away.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:17
verses.text: Marriages of that sort are quickly dissolved when lust is satiated.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:18
verses.text: The first allurement gone, the charm is lost.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:19
verses.text: What shall I say, says Seneca, of the poor men who in numbers are bribed to take the name of husband in order to evade the laws promulgated against bachelors? How can he who is married under such conditions be a guide to morality, teach chastity, and maintain the authority of a husband? It is the saying of a very learned man, that chastity must be preserved at all costs, and that when it is lost all virtue falls to the ground.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:20
verses.text: This holds the primacy of all virtues in woman.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:21
verses.text: This it is that makes up for a wife's poverty, enhances her riches, redeems her deformity, gives grace to her beauty; it makes her act in a way worthy of her forefathers whose blood it does not taint with bastard offspring; of her children, who through it have no need to blush for their mother, or to be in doubt about their father; and above all, of herself, since it defends her from external violation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:22
verses.text: There is no greater calamity connected with captivity than to be the victim of another's lust.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:23
verses.text: The consulship sheds lustre upon men; eloquence gives eternal renown; military glory and a triumph immortalise an obscure family.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:24
verses.text: Many are the spheres ennobled by splendid ability.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:25
verses.text: The virtue of woman is, in a special sense, purity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:26
verses.text: It was this that madeLucretia the equal of Brutus, if it did not make her his superior, since Brutus learnt from a woman the impossibility of being a slave.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:27
verses.text: It was this that madeCornelia a fit match for Gracchus, andPorcia for a second Brutus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:28
verses.text: Tanaquil is better known than her husband.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:29
verses.text: His name, like the names of many other kings, is lost in the mists of antiquity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:30
verses.text: She, through a virtue rare among women, is too deeply rooted in the hearts of all ages for her memory ever to perish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against Jovinianus Book I 49:31
verses.text: Let my married sisters copy the examples ofTheano,Cleobuline, Gorgente,Timoclia, theClaudias and Cornelias; and when they find the Apostle conceding second marriage to depraved women, they will read that before the light of our religion shone upon the world wives of one husband ever held high rank among matrons, that by their hands the sacred rites of Fortuna Muliebris were performed, that a priest orFlamen twice married was unknown, that the high-priests of Athens to this day emasculate themselves by drinking hemlock, and once they have been drawn in to the pontificate, cease to be men.
